loans.name: Akua

texts.en: Akua is 51 years old. She is married and the mother of seven children. Four of her children are adults, while the other three are still in school. She enjoys selling goods, a business where she makes a living. She has been selling tubers of yam, cereals like gari, and beans for four years now to support her family. She treks to farming communities to buy her stock from the farmers. This saves her from intermediaries who buy from the farmers and resell to her at higher prices. She also deals in the sale of scrap materials; she collects them in pieces and sells them to companies for further processing. She wants to use the loan to buy yarn, beans, and gari in bulk to meet the daily demands of her customers as they approach the Christmas holiday. She hopes to use part of her profits to support her children in school and to expand her business to the level she desires. She would be grateful for your loan assistance.

loans.use: To buy yam, cereals and beans in bulk.

loans.name: Phelomina

texts.en: Phelomina M. A. sells raw rice, onions, canned tomatoes and other items at the sea shore. Phelomina has no formal education. She is married and has two children. Her husband is a trader. Phelomina has been selling these items since 2004. She helps her husband with payments for school fees and utility bills. Her loan will be used to buy more bags of rice and onions and more canned tomatoes for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to save and reinvest.

loans.use: Her loan will be used to buy more bags of rice and onions and more canned tomatoes for sale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is twenty-nine years old. She is married and has two children who are both in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. Mary works hard to help her husband provide for the family. She runs a chop bar in her community. Mary buys her goods from nearby communities. She has been in business for barely a year and desires to improve upon her business. Mary desires to give her children a good education.

loans.use: To buy food stuffs for sale

loans.name: Yaa

texts.en: Yaa is a 37-year-old woman. She is married with seven children who are all currently in school. She lives at Offinso in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She is a food vendor and serves food like rice and stew. Her food is moderate and affordable. For that reason, lots of people buy from her stand. She says demand for food is on the higher side but she does not have adequate funds for expansion. She has been selling rice and gravy stew for five years. Her proceeds are used to take care of the children's school bills and other household responsibilities. She wants to use the loan to buy meat and rice to increase her efficiency and produce in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business and provide more income to help her husband support her family and their education. She dreams of providing her children with a better education to give them a better future.

loans.use: To buy more rice, vegetables, meat, firewood etc.

loans.name: Edwin Rene

texts.es:
El Señor C. esta casado con 2 hijos de edades de 5 y 2 años,  su esposa trabaja como comerciante,  el inicio su negocio de elaboración de muebles hace 10 años.
El esta solicitando su crédito para comprar tela, madera y esponja para construir más muebles,  en su tienda en donde vende muebles tiene 1 empleados y en la fábrica tiene 5 empleados.
El ha tenido 3 créditos grupales con FAPE y ha sido muy cumplido con sus compromisos y este es su primer préstamo con Kiva.
Su sueño es ampliar su local para venta de muebles.
texts.en:
Edwin Rene is married with a 5-year old and a 2-year old. His wife works in retail. He started his furniture making business 10 years ago.

He is requesting a loan to buy fabric, wood and foam to build more furniture. His furniture store has one employee and the factory has 5 employees.

He has requested 3 group loans with FAPE and has always complied with his commitments. This is his first Kiva loan.

His dream is to expand his furniture store.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fabric, wood and foam to build furniture

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Comfort is 50 years old. She is divorced and has four children who are all in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. Comfort works hard to be able to provide for the family. She is a food vendor. She prepares and sells rice and wheat porridge. She hawks to sell in the mornings. Comfort buys bags of rice from nearby towns. She has been in business for two years and wants a loan to procure bags of rice and other ingredients in bulk so she can increase her profit margin.

loans.use: To buy bags of rice in bulk

loans.name: Hagar

texts.en: Hagar is a 38-year-old woman. She is married with four children who are currently in school. She lives in Offinsu in the Ashanti region of Ghana. She is a food vendor and serves food like rice and stew. She says demand for food is on the higher side but she does not have adequate funds for expansion. She has been in food production for six years. Hagar works but still she can’t increase her output. She wants to use the loan to buy meat and bags of rice to produce in larger quantities. She believes this will help expand her business to raise more income to help her husband support her family and their education.

loans.use: To buy more rice, vegetables, meat, firewood etc.

loans.name: Justina

texts.en: Justina is 27 years old. She is married and has one child who is in school. She lives with her husband and daughter in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. She works hard to help her husband provide for the family. Justina trades in crates of eggs. She supplies to retailers and other food vendors in her community. Justina buys crates of eggs from nearby towns. She has been in business for seven years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy crates of eggs

loans.name: Nana

texts.en: Nana K. is married and has three children. She has no formal education.  Nana sells canned tomatoes and oil at Mrin Park near Elmina in Cape Coast. She has been doing this since 1995. Her husband is a driver.  Nana uses his income to pay school fees and utility bills. Nana will use the loan to buy gallons of oil and tomatoes for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Nana plans to save to buy land.

loans.use: To buy oil and tomatoes to sell

loans.name: Amatista Group

texts.es: Margarita, Julian, Mery, Martha, Arminda, Marina, Claudia, Olivia, Fanny, Patricia, Nancy, Senaida, Rosmery y Frida, son las 14  integrantes del grupo Amatista, que tienen diversos negocios como la venta  de material de construcción, venta de chuño (papa deshidratada), venta de jugo de naranja, venta de ropa, atención de tienda de abarrotes y venta de comida. En esta época de fin de año desean mejorar sus ingresos y para ello necesitan un préstamo para comprar mercadería y seguir adelante en sus negocios. Así por ejemplo Fanny de 37 años vende jugo de naranja en diferentes ferias de la ciudad de El Alto y necesita el préstamo para comprar naranja.
texts.en:
Margarita, Julian, Mery, Martha, Arminda, Marina, Claudia, Olivia, Fanny, Patricia, Nancy, Senaida, Rosmery, and Frida are the 14 members of the Amatista group. They have various diverse businesses, such as construction materials, chuño [dried potatoes], orange juice, clothing, grocery store, and food sales.

In this end of year season, they want to increase their profits, and for this they need a loan to buy merchandise and move ahead in their businesses. For example, Fanny, 37 years old, sells orange juice in various markets in the city of El Alto. She needs a loan to purchase more oranges.

Translated from Spanish by jeffrey hersk, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase merchandise

loans.name: María

texts.es: María tiene 53 años, vive al lado de sus tres hijos de 17, 16 y 8 años, todos habitan en su acogedora casa que es propia.Desde hace 3 años se dedica a la venta de jugos ya que le resulta muy rentable y no tiene pierde porque son muy solicitados debido a la exquisitez  de su sabor por la frescura de la fruta con la que prepara; abastece a sus vecinos los que  le pagan todo el mes por anticipado para que María les reparta su jugo diario. Como es una mujer muy dinámica y siempre esta incursionando en nuevos negocios, casi nunca tiene tiempo, ya que las pocas horas de su tiempo libre se las dedica por entero a su familia. Las ventas son buenas y espera seguir prosperando pero para realizarlo  sabe que debe esforzarse y así en el  futuro tiene pensado  aperturar una tienda de comestibles, pero por el momento le va bien con su pequeño negocio y espera seguir en la venta de jugos y golosinas por algún tiempo más ya que  ha hecho  buenos amigos durante las ventas, además que  los ingresos son muy rentables.Es su  quinto préstamo con  MFP, y promete ser puntual y responsable en cada uno de sus pagos como siempre lo ha hecho.Con el dinero del crédito  comprará mayor cantidad de mercadería (frutas) y golosinas para aumentar las ventas en su negocio.
texts.en:
María is 53 years old and lives with her three children ages 17, 16 and 8. They all live in the cozy home she owns. She started selling juice 3 years ago. It has been very profitable because of the high demand of juice due to the exquisite flavor and the freshness of the fruit she prepares it with. She supplies her neighbors who pay in advance every month for Maria to serve them daily.

Since she is a very dynamic woman and is always trying new businesses, she is always very busy. The little spare time she has is fully dedicated to her family. Sales have been good and she expects to keep growing but she knows it takes hard work. She has been thinking about opening a food store but for the time being she is doing well with her small business and expects to continue selling juice and candy for some more time. She has made good friends through her sales and the income is very good.

This is her fifth loan with MFP and she assures she will be on time and compliant with each of her payment, as she has always been. She will use the loan to purchase more inventory (fruit and candy) to increase her sales.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: More inventory to supply her business

loans.name: Richard

texts.en: Richard is thirty years of age. He is married and has two children who are currently in school. He lives with his wife and children in a rented apartment. They live in a tourist attraction community in the central region of Ghana. The community is one of the coastal towns in Ghana. As a result, the occupation of the people is mainly fishing. Richard is a trader. He runs a provision store by the roadside in the community. He procures his goods from Accra. Richard has been in business for five years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to increase his stock.

loans.use: To buy provisions for his store.

loans.name: Olaribigbé

texts.fr: O. Olaribigbé est née le 31 Juillet 1960 à Parakou, dans le Nord du Bénin. Mariée à AGBE Michel, un chauffeur, Olaribigbé est mère de sept enfants, dont trois sont à sa charge. La famille réside depuis 13ans à PK10 Enafa, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Olaribigbé n’a jamais été à l’école. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Olaribigbé vend des condiments de sauce et divers autres produits (oeufs, sucres, savons, cube, etc.) à son domicile. Olaribigbé s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Olaribigbé a 10 ans d’expérience dans ce domaine, et est à son cinquième crédit à ALIDé. Olaribigbé manque de moyens financiers en ces périodes, pour renforcer davantage son activité et répondre à la demande de ses clients. C’est la raison pour laquelle Olaribigbé sollicite un cinquième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
O. Olaribigbé was born on July 31, 1960 in Parakou, in northern Bénin. She is married to Agbe Michel, a driver, and is the mother of seven children, three of whom are still dependents. The family has lived in PK10 Enafa, in the commune of Sèmè-Podji, for 13 years. The couple take care of family expenses together. Olaribigbé never went to school.
To provide for her children, Olaribigbé sells condiment sauces and various other products (eggs, sugar, soap, stock cubes, etc.) outside her home. Olaribigbé stocks up in Dantokpa, at the international market of Bénin. She has 10 years experience in this trade and is on her fifth loan with Alidé. At the moment, Olaribigbé lacks sufficient funds to maintain her business and meet customer demands. That’s why she is requesting her fifth Alidé loan.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy tomatoes, spices, onions, eggs and sugar

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is a businesswoman. She trades in Dumas clothes, linen and lace materials. She sells mostly through hawking. Her personal selling method, she says, makes her goods move very fast.  She is 55 years old and married. She is mother to six children.  All of her children are currently in school. She is very supportive to her family through her trading business. She takes delivery of goods from Kumasi and retails to her customers. She has been in business for the past seven years, while taking care of her family. She hopes the loan will enable her to reinforce her business and to make more viable profit. She wants to buy more goods so that she can take advantage, over this Christmas, to increase her sales and, hence, her profit margin. She would be grateful for your support.

loans.use: To purchase bulk  Dumas clothes to increase her inventory.

loans.name: Juana Natividad

texts.es:
La socia Juana es natural de la ciudad de Urcos de la provincia de Quispicanchis del departamento del Cusco y pertenece al Banco Comunal “Qori Orcco” de la Asociación Arariwa. Nuestra socia Juana tiene 52 años, es casada y tiene tres hijos y dos ya no depende de ella pero el ultimo hijo llamado Joel tiene 12 años y estudia en el colegio.

La socia se levanta muy temprano para hacer sus actividades del hogar como cocinar para su menor hijo y lo deja la comida para que él se sirva al medio día. La socia después de hacer sus actividades del hogar tiene que trabajar para Municipalidad de Urcos en el sector de limpieza publica, su labor es limpiar calles, plazas y parques de la cuidad de Urcos. La socia nos cuenta que tiene un pequeño taller de artesanía donde trabajo su hija Rosmery. Ya son varios años que tienen el negocio y les ha ido muy bien, gracias a todo el empeño que ponen en su trabajo. Nuestra socia es una madre trabajadora y emprendedora que requiere el préstamo para comprar más material como lana, telas, hilos y cuero para crear más artesanía. 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Juana is a native of the city of Urcos in the Quispicanchis province of the department of Cusco. She belongs to the communal bank "Qori Orcco" which is part of the Arariwa Association. Juana is 52 years old, married, and has 3 children. Two of the children are no longer dependent but the last son, named Joel, is 12 years old and studies in school. Juana gets up very early to complete her household work such as cooking for her youngest son; she leaves the meal for him to eat at midday. Later, after she finishes her activities in the home, she has to work for the Municipality of Urcos in the public cleaning department where she cleans streets, plazas and parks in the city of Urcos. She tells us that she has a small handicraft workshop where her daughter Rosmery works. She has had this business for some years now, and it has gone very well, thanks to all of the effort she puts into her work. She is a hardworking and enterprising mother who needs a loan to buy more material such as wool, fabrics, thread and leather to make more crafts. Juana is grateful for the opportunity provided through these means, and pledges to make the payments according to the established schedule.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy more raw materials such as wool, fabric, thread and leather

loans.name: Christiana

texts.en: Christiana is forty-two years old. She is married and has given birth to one child who is in school. She lives with her husband and son in a rented apartment in a fishing community, in the central region of Ghana. Christiana works hard to support her husband to provide for the family. She runs a chop bar in her community. She buys her goods from nearby communities. Christiana has been in business for two years and desires to improve upon her business. She desires to give all her children a good education.

loans.use: To buy food items for the business.

loans.name: Rachelle

texts.fr: M. Rachelle est née le 18 Janvier 1962 et vit depuis environs 7 ans à PK10 Marina, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Mariée à ODOULAMI Daniel, un chauffeur, Rachelle est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Tous les enfants vivent ensemble avec leurs parents à PK10 Marina. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Rachelle a arrêté l’école au cours secondaire. Depuis environs 10 ans, Rachelle vend des tissus, de la friperie et quelquefois des bijoux de façon ambulante. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Rachelle s’approvisionne. Rachelle a déjà obtenu deux crédits à ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Rachelle sollicite un troisième crédit de ALIDé, en vue de renforcer davantage son activité et de répondre efficacement à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
M. Rachelle was born on January 18, 1962. She has lived in PK10 Marina, in the Sèmè-Podji Commune, in Bénin, for around 7 years. She is married to Odoulami Daniel, a driver, and is the mother of three children who are all educated. They all live together in PK10 Marina, and she and her husband cover the family’s expenses together. Rachelle did not complete secondary school.
For almost 10 years, Rachelle has worked as a street vendor selling cloth, second hand clothing and sometimes jewellery. Rachelle stocks up in Dantokpa, at the international market of Bénin.
Rachelle has already received and repaid two loans through Alidé. She is requesting a third Alidé loan to expand her business and meet customer demands.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy 25 lengths of cloth

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary E. is married and has three children. She has received a senior high education.  Mary operates a provisions shop in which she sells raw rice, fresh eggs, powdered milk, and bags of water and so on at Chapel Square near Elmina, which she has been doing since 2003. Her husband is a teacher.  Mary uses her income to support her husband in the payment of school fess and utility bills.  Mary will use the loan to buy more bags of rice and bags of water and so on for sale. With the new profits from her expanded business, Mary plans to open a container store.

loans.use: Mary will use the loan to buy more bags of rice and bags of water and so on to sell.

loans.name: Nanci Paola

texts.es:
La señora Nanci tiene 27 años, esta casada y tiene 3 hijos, edades de 10 años, 2 años y 5 meses,  su esposo se dedica a la elaboración de muebles y su hija mayor esta entrando al 4to. año de primaria.   
Su comedor esta ubicado en un área urabana y tiene 2 años de tenerlo,  también se dedica a vender ropa ambulantemente,  ella va invertir el crédito en comprar chumpas y trajes de niños para su venta de ropa y también para comprar platos para su comedor.  
Tiene 3 años de trabajar en banco comunal de FAPE y este será su primer crédito con Kiva,  su sueño es tener un local para vender su ropa y ya no vender ambulantemente.  También le gustaría darle más apoyo a su esposo en el crecimiento de su venta de muebles.
texts.en:
Nanci is 27 years old, married, and has 3 children ages 10, 2 and 5 months. Her husband has a business making furniture and her oldest daughter is entering her 4th year of primary school. She has had a restaurant for 2 years that is located in an urban area. In addition she sells clothing in the streets. She will use this loan to purchase jackets and suits for children for her clothing business and to buy plates for her restaurant. She has worked with the communal bank FAPE for 3 years, and this will be her first loan with Kiva. Her dream is to have a place to sell her clothes so that she does not have to sell them in the streets. In addition, she would like to give more support to her husband and help him to grow his business selling furniture.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: capital for her restaurant and her clothing business

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en: Joyce is 50 years old. She is married and the mother of five children. Currently, all her children are independent, except her last born who is in school. She is very resourceful to her family in provision of food and payment of bills. She is a food vendor and sells kenkey with fried fish with spice pepper. She sells kenkey in the mornings and in the afternoon. Kenkey is prepared from milled maize grains, cooked and taken with hot pepper and fried fish. She has many customers since many Ghanaian enjoy kenkey as breakfast, lunch and supper. She wants to use the loan to buy more raw materials like bags of maize, meat, fish, vegetables and firewood. She hopes to increase her savings to support her children’s education and she hopes to use part of her profit to improve her savings and business growth.

loans.use: To buy more raw materials to make kenkey.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia, 34, a married mother of four children who are all in school, lives with her family in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. Working hard to support her husband to provide for the family, Lydia buys cabbages from nearby farming communities and then sells them to retailers and other food vendors in her community. She also sells at the local market. Lydia has been in business for five years and wants a loan to procure goods in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy cabbages

loans.name: Selina

texts.en: Selina is 44 years old. She is married and is the mother of three children. Currently, one is in school while the rest of the children are on their own. She works hard to maintain her business. She is a petty trader and trades in foodstuffs like tomatoes, onions, peppers, smoked and dried fish, yams, and plantains, which she sells on top of a table in bulk in the market. She takes delivery of goods from the surrounding villages and purchases some from Kumasi Central Market. Her problem now has to do with adequate business funding to make progress. With the loan, she believes her dream of buying more stock can be achieved. She would be grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: To buy vegetables like onions, peppers, and tomatoes

loans.name: God's Time Group

texts.en: Barbara is thirty-eight years old. She is a wife and the mother of two children who are currently in school. She sells pastries such as meat pies and donuts. Barbara is constrained by a lack of funds needed to run the business. She needs the loan to inject more working capital into the business in order to scale up her business progress. She is the leader of a village trust bank group called God’s Time. All the members are engaged in trading. They work so hard to put food on the tables of their households and also to support their kids' schooling. They believe the loan will help them to have more resources to purchase food ingredients and stock in bulk to meet their customers' demands. They believe your support would enable them to grow their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase food ingredients and stock

loans.name: Efua

texts.en: Efua is sixty years old. She is divorced and has given birth to eight children, all of whom are in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. Efua works hard to be able to provide for the family. She is a trader. She trades maize. Efua supplies the maize to food vendors in her community. She also treks to nearby towns to supply food vendors there. Efua buys bags of maize from nearby farming communities. She has been in business for over twenty years and wants a loan to procure bags of maize in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize

loans.name: Costeñitas Ii Group

texts.es:
Venta de verduras, elaboración de masitas (repostería), atención de tienda de barrio,  venta de cosméticos, venta de golosinas, venta de comida, producción de muebles, venta de ropa para niño son los diferentes negocios de las integrantes del grupo Costeñitas II, que a su vez realizan sus reuniones en el Centro Focal Exaltación, una de las integrantes es Miriam Villa una joven de 22 años ella vende ropa para bebe y va ofreciendo a diferentes personas, ferias, domicilios, es decir es ambulante.
Todas están esperanzadas en fortalecer y hacer crecer sus negocios y necesitan préstamo para comprar mercadería en los casos de negocios de comercialización, materia prima las que se dedican a la producción.
texts.en:
Sales of vegetables, pastry-making, general store, cosmetics sales, candy sales, food sales, furniture making, children's clothing sales are the different types of business of the members of the Costeñitas II group. The group holds its meetings in the Centro Focal Exaltación.

One of the members is Miriam, a 22 year old who sells baby clothing. She offers her products to people in markets and homes, she is a travelling salesperson.

They are all hopeful to streghten and increase their business. They need the loan to buy inventory, in the case of the commercial businesses and raw materials, in the case of production businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of inventory and raw materials

loans.name: Akua

texts.en:
Akua is 36 years old. She is married and the mother of five children. All of her children are currently in school. She is very humble and committed to her work and her family's needs. She believes that her children are her assets. 

Akua sells smoked fish in bulk at the community market in her neighborhood.  She has been sixteen years of sales experience. She purchases her stock from Yeji in the Brong Ahafo region of Ghana and sells it retail to her customers. Sometimes she spends more time in Yeji so that she can buy good quality dried and smoked fish. This helps her avoid frequent travel and purchasing through middlemen. 

She requests a loan to buy more stock to upgrade her inventory.  Ajua is grateful for your assistance.

loans.use: to buy smoked fish in bulk

loans.name: Faustina

texts.en:
Faustina is thirty–eight years old. She is married and has given birth to three children.  All of her children are in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing dominated community in the central region of Ghana. 

Faustina is a trader. She sells footwear for both males and females. She hawks and treks to nearby communities to sell on their market days. Faustina has been in this business for three years and wants to give her business a facelift. Therefore, she is requesting a loan to procure more goods.

loans.use: To buy second-hand bags

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.fr: A. Bernadette est née en 1961 et vit depuis 18 ans à Davatin dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Mariée à DOHETO Honoré, un cuisinier, Bernadette est mère de cinq enfants, tous scolarisés. Il n’y a que trois des enfants qui soient à sa charge. La famille vit ensemble à Davatin. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Bernadette n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Pour assurer ses besoins et ceux de ses enfants, Bernadette vend divers produits de beauté (lait corporel, eau de toilette, savons, déodorants, parfums etc.) de façon ambulante. Bernadette mène comme activité secondaire, la vente de «sodabi» (boisson alcoolisée locale) à son domicile. Bernadette s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Bernadette est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de quatre crédits auprès de l’institution. Bernadette a bien remboursé les quatre crédits qu’elle a obtenus de ALIDé. Bernadette sollicite un cinquième crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d’accroître son activité et de mieux satisfaire la demande des clients.
texts.en:
Bernadette A. was born in 1961 and has been living for the past 18 years in the Davatin area of Sèmè-Podji, in Benin. She is married to Honoré DOHETO, a cook, and is mother of five children, all educated, of which three are still in her care. The family lives together in Davatin, and the couple share household expenses. Bernadette has not attended school. To meet her own and her children's needs, Bernadette sells a variety of beauty products (body lotion, eau de toilette, soaps, deodorants, perfumes, etc.) as an itinerant vendor. Bernadette's second business activity is selling "sodabi" (a local alcoholic beverage) from her home. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Bernadette is a former client of ALIDé, having previously been granted four loans with the organisation, all of which have been fully reimbursed. She now requests a fifth loan from ALIDé, to increase her activities and better respond to her customer's needs.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy boxes of beauty products (body lotions, beauty soaps, perfumes, deodorants, powders)

loans.name: Diana

texts.en:
Diana O. has two children. She supports her husband in the payment of school fees and utility bills. She has received a senior high school education. 

Diana sells cooked rice with tomato sauce at Chapel Square near Elmina. She has been engaged in this business since 2001. Her loan will be used to buy more rice and ingredients to prepare food for sale. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to build a house.

loans.use: to buy more rice and ingredients used to prepare food for sale

loans.name: Vicencias

texts.fr: K. Vicencias est née vers 1960 et vit depuis une dizaine d’année à Lokokoukoumè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Vicencias est mariée à BONOU Etienne, un frigoriste. Le couple a six enfants, tous scolarisés, dont trois sont à leur charge. Vicencias vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Vicencias n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire. Pour assurer ses besoins, Vicencias vend depuis près de trois ans, des beignets et du pâté (aliment fait à base de farine de blé, du sucre et de l'huile) à son domicile. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Vicencias s’approvisionne. Vicencias a déjà bénéficié de trois crédits qui ont été  bien remboursés à ALIDé. Face à la demande de plus en plus nombreuse de la clientèle, Vicencias n’arrive plus à satisfaire tous ses clients. C’est ce qui l’amène à solliciter un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Vicencias K. was born around 1960 and has been living for the past 10 years in the Lokokoukoumé area of Sèmè-podji, in Benin. Vicencias is married to Etienne BONOU, a refrigeration specialist. The couple have six children, all educated, of which three are still under their care. Vicencias lives together with her husband and children, and the couple share household expenses. Vicencias has only attended primary school. To meet her needs over the past three years, Vicencias has been selling fritters and pâté (foodstuff made from wheat flour, sugar and oil) from her home. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, Benin's international market. Vicencias has already been granted three loans that were fully reimbursed to ALIDé. Given the increasing number of requests from her customers, Vicencias is unable to satisfy all of them. This is why she is now requesting a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bags of wheat flour and cans of peanut oil

loans.name: Antonio

texts.es:
Desde muy temprano Antonio Muñoz, en su casa del barrio Villa del Carmen de Soledad-Atlántico, inicia el día moliendo carne bien sazonada y con la cual rellena una tripa natural prealistada, sometida a altas temperaturas, que amarra con un hilo de pita, para darle su singular forma de cadeneta; es así como la prepara para la cocción y apertura de orificos, a fin de que posteriormente se recoja y quede lista para degustarla.  De esta manera Antonio, elabora un embutido artesanal, llamado “Butifarra” típico de Soledad –Atlántico, donde la proliferación de estas unidades artesanales ha ido disminuyendo, pues actualmente  ha sido copiado y forma parte de la línea de producto de grandes empresas carnicas que son su máxima competencia; aunque como lo expresa Antonio, a esas industrias no le queda este producto con el exquisito sabor costeño y por eso su clientela sabe lo que come, lo prefieren y lo buscan en el municipio de Soledad, el cual se ha hecho famoso por este producto inspirador de típicas y hermosas canciones compuestas por artistas de nuestra Región Atlanticense e incluidas en álbumes  “Joyas de la Música Colombiana”.

Antonio, llegó a Barranquilla, procedente de Pedraza-Bolívar su tierra natal, donde se dedicaba a labores del campo, pero su deseo de encontrar un mejor futuro hizo que se trasladara a la Capital del Atlántico; fue así como trabajó en la venta de cocadas inicialmente y luego en una microempresa ubicada en el Municipio de soledad, dedicada a lo que hoy es su único ingreso familiar “la fabricación y comercialización de butifarreras”, actividad con la que ha logrado darle educación a sus hijos en compañía de sus esposa. Aunque él, no estudió, aprendió a firmar y a trabajar con amor, para educar a sus  3 hijos  pensando en que  estudiando construirían un mejor futuro, así lleva 19 años vendiendo butifarra y su hija  menor, estudia en el Sena, una carrera técnica y también comercializa este producto. 

Su primer crédito con la Fundación Santo Domingo, lo  hizo hace 17 años por valor de $30.000, cuando conformó con cuatro amigos el grupo solidario  llamado “Luz de Luz”. Desde ese momento el popular Antonio, ha recibido 14 créditos, gradualmente aumentados en la medida de expansión de su mercado; su capacidad de trabajo y deseo de superación permitieron que  en el año 1995 comprara un lote, para construir lo que hoy es su vivienda, la cual ha ido levantando poco a poco, con el producto de su trabajo en la fabricación de la exquisita y muy Caribe butifarra. 

Antonio, es un experto en captar la atención de clientes en espacios de gran afluencia pública, con su hija vende al detalle en sitios muy estratégicos y es bien conocido como una persona responsable y honesta. Su próximo crédito por valor de  $1.300.000 lo utilizará para  comprar materias primas e  insumos,  especialmente, carne de res, cerdo y pollo, para incluir variedad en la elaboración del producto y poder vender en volumen, apoyándose en los vecinos del barrio donde vive, quienes también se han convertido en vendedores de su producto en los picos de alta productividad y comercialización.

Su  próximo desafío es continuar con las mejoras de su vivienda, especialmente piso, baño y pintura, el dice que el apoyo de su familia en el manejo del negocio es fundamental para que todo esto suceda.
texts.en:
Antonio Muños begins his day in the early morning at his home in the Villa del Carmen neighborhood of Soledad-Atlántico, grinding seasoned meat which he uses to stuff natural sausage casings. He ties the casings with string to form links. He prepares it for cooking and later enjoying. This is how Antonio prepares a delicious sausage called “Butifarra,” typical in Soledad-Atlántico, where these small operations are going away and their culinary arts have been copied by large meat processing plants, which give great completion. Antonio says that these companies’ products are not as tasty, so his customers seek him out in Soledad and he has become famous for his product, which has lead to lovely inspirational songs by artisans form the Atlanticense region. These songs have been included in the album “Joyas de la Música Colombiana” (Jewels of Columbian Music). Antonia arrived in Barranquilla from his native land in Pedraza-Bolívar where has worked in the fields, but his desire for a better life inspired him to move to Atlántico where he initially sold “cocadas,” (sweetened meat candy). He later worked in a small factory in Soledad, which make butifarra. This allowed him and his wife to provide for his three children’s educations. Although he did not receive a formal education, he learned to work and write so that he could educate his children because he believes that a good education will give them a better future. He has been selling butifarra for 19 years. His youngest daughter studies in el Sena and also sells his product. He got his first loan for $30 through “la Fundación Santo Domingo” (The Santo Domingo Foundation) 17 years ago when he and four friends formed the group “Luz de Luz” (Light from Light). Since then Antonio has received fourteen incrementally larger loans to expand his market. His ability to work and desire to get ahead allowed him to buy a vacant lot in 1995. Little by little he built his home with the income he made from the sale of his delicious product. Antonio is an expert in attracting customers in wealthy areas. He and his daughter sell in strategic locations and he is well known for being honest and responsible. He will use the money from his next loan of $1,300 for supplies, especially beef, pork and chicken in order to offer greater variety and be able to sell in larger quantities and support his neighbors who also sell his product during the high season. His next challenge is to continue improving his home, particularly the floors, bathroom and painting. He says that his family’s support in managing his business is important to seeing this through.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies, especially beef, pork and chicken

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To expand and improve their business by purchasing quality fishing equipment

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es: Nancy de 42 años, es una mujer muy trabajadora, vive en su casa propia al lado de sus dos hijos Jaime de 12 y Miguel Alfonso de 14 años.Desde hace 4 años se dedica a la costura, trabaja en asociación con unas amigas cosiendo creativos adornos a las blusas que le traen  por cantidad, para que hagan los acabados que en su mayoría son de mostacillas y lentejuelas. A Nancy le gusta mucho su trabajo y es por esta razón  que lo realiza con muchas ganas, aunque muchas veces se le hace rutinario  y algo  difícil  ya que  debe tener muy buena vista y precisión para realizarlo , aún así termina todas las blusas en el plazo estipulado y obtiene buenas ganancias .Es su primer crédito con MFP y promete ser  muy responsable con todos sus pagos.Con el dinero del crédito quiere comprar más cantidad de material para producir mejor los pedidos que le realizan, y así obtener mayores ganancias económicas.
texts.en:
Nancy is 42 years old, and is a very enterprising woman who lives in her own house along with her two sons: Jaime, 12, and Miguel Alfonso, who is 14 years old. For 4 years she has been making clothing; she works in partnership with several friends sewing creative decorations on blouses that they buy in large quantity so that they can do finishes that are mostly made of beads and sequins. Nancy loves her work and for this reason she performs it with great eagerness, although it is often routine and somewhat difficult in that you must have very good vision and accuracy to do it. Still, she finishes all of the shirts on time and earns good profits. This is her first loan with MFP and she promises to be very responsible with all of her payments. With the money requested she wants to buy a greater quantity of material so that she can fulfill her orders better and thus obtain better earnings.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy merchandise to continue with her work

loans.name: Akouavi Rita

texts.fr: A. Akouavi Rita est née en 1968 à Comè, dans le département du Mono au Bénin. Akouavi Rita s’est installée à Lokokoukoumè, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, il y a environs neuf ans. Mariée à ANATO Médard, un agent permanent de l’Etat, Akouavi Rita est mère de sept enfants, dont cinq sont à sa charge. Seulement certains enfants sont scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble à Lokokoukoumè. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Akouavi Rita n’a pas été à l’école. Pour aider son mari dans les charges de la famille, Akouavi Rita vend des divers (farine de manioc, sucre, lait, conserves, savons, pâtes alimentaires, sardines, fil à coudre, etc.) à son domicile. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Akouavi Rita s’approvisionne. Akouavi Rita a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Akouavi Rita sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin de renforcer son capital et d’élever le niveau de son activité pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Akouavi Rita A. was born in 1968 in Comè, in the Mono department of Benin. About nine years ago, Akouavi Rita settled in the Lokokoukoumè area of Sèmè-Podji. She is married to Médard ANATO, a government agent, and mother of seven children, five of whom are still under her care. Only some of the children are educated. The family lives together in Lokokoukoumè, and the couple share household expenses. Akouavi Rita has not been to school. To help her husband meet household expenses, Akouavi Rita sells various goods from her home (manioc flour, sugar, milk, canned food, soap, pasta, sardines, sewing thread, etc.). She gets her supplies from the international market of Benin, Dantokpa. Akouavi Rita has already benefited from two loans from ALIDé, that were both repaid in full. She now requests a third loan from ALIDé, to strengthen her capital base and increase her level of activity to better satisfy her customers.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy boxes of sugar, milk, canned food and soap

loans.name: Nyame Akwan Group

texts.en:
Stephen is a petty trader and trades in agro-chemicals. He purchases agro-chemicals such as fertilizers and weedicides from wholesalers in the cities, and he sells these in retail to farmers in his town. From this business, he supports his family and finances all of his children's educations.

He is the leader of a village trust bank group called “Nyame Akwan” (God’s Way). The group's members are all traders and food vendors who support their families through their businesses. They want to use the loan to purchase stock in bulk to avoid costly price hikes and also to cut down on frequent travels. They are expecting to make higher profits this season, which will allow them to support their families and pay their kids' school fees. Your support through this loan would enable them to grow their businesses.

Stephen is 45 years old. He is married and the father of four children who are currently pursuing education in senior, junior, and primary schools. He lives with his family in their own house in a farming community.

loans.use: To purchase stock in bulk

loans.name: Rakiétou

texts.fr: T. Rakiétou est née en 1976 à Djougou dans le Nord du Bénin. Mariée à SOUMANOU Yacoubou, un chauffeur, Rakiétou est mère de trois enfants, dont deux sont à sa charge. Seulement certains de ses enfants sont scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble au quartier Finagnon à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin, depuis environs trois ans. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Rakiétou n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Il y a une dizaine d’année que Rakiétou vend de la nourriture (riz et haricot, accompagné de friture, etc.) à son domicile. Rakiétou s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Rakiétou a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits auprès de ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. La demande des clients se fait de plus en plus nombreuse ; mais Rakiétou ne dispose plus suffisamment de moyens financiers pour satisfaire la demande de tous les clients. C’est la raison pour laquelle Rakiétou sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Rakiétou T. was born in 1976 in Djougou, in the North of Benin. She is married to Yacoubou SOUMANOU, a driver, and is the mother of three children, two of which are still under her care. Only some of her children are educated. The family has been living together for approximately three years in the Finagnon area of Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin, and the couple share household expenses. Rakiétou has not been to school. Rakiétou has been selling food from her home for the past ten years: rice and beans, with fried food, etc. She gets her supplies from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. Rakiétou has already been granted two loans from ALIDé, that were both fully repaid. Customer demand is now increasing to the point where Rakiétou no longer has the financial means to satisfy all of her customers. For this reason she is now requesting a third loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy bags of rice and beans, and sauce ingredients (tomatoes, onions, chillies)

loans.name: God's Gift Group

texts.en:
John, age 30, runs a grocery store, and this is his main source of income to support his family. He is married and the father of two children, both of whom are enrolled in school. He lives with his family in their own house in a farming community.

John is the leader of a village trust bank group called "God’s Gift." The members are all traders and food vendors who support their families through these businesses. They want to use the loan to purchase stock in bulk to avoid costly price hikes and also to cut down on frequent travels. They are expecting to make higher profits this season, and this will help them support their families and pay their kids' school fees. Your support through this loan would enable them to grow their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase stock in bulk

loans.name: Laure

texts.fr: A. Laure est née le 30 Octobre 1975 et vit depuis près de 19 ans à PK10 Marina, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Laure est mariée à AGBO Donald, un informaticien. Le couple a trois enfants, mais seulement certains enfants sont scolarisés. Laure vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Laure n’a fréquenté que l’école primaire, et a appris ensuite la couture. Laure exerce cette activité depuis environs 10 ans. Laure vend également des tissus et des produits de mercerie dans son atelier se trouvant à son domicile. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Laure s’approvisionne. Laure est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de trois crédits auprès de l’institution, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Laure voudrait renforcer son activité pour mieux répondre à la demande de ses clients. C’est pourquoi Laure sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
Laure A. was born October 30, 1975 and has been living for the past 19 years in PK10 Marina, in the Sèmè-Podji district of Benin. She is married to Donald AGBO, a computer specialist. The couple have three children, but only some of them are educated. Laure lives together with her husband and children, and the couple share household expenses. Laure has only attended primary school, after which she learned sewing. Laure has been sewing for approximately ten years. She also sells fabrics and haberdashery supplies from her home-based workshop. She goes to Dantokpa, Benin's international market, for her supplies. Laure is a former client of ALIDé, having already been granted three loans by the organisation, all of which were repaid in full. She would like to increase her activities so that she can give better response to customer requests. This is why she is now applying for a fourth loan from ALIDé.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy pieces of fabric and haberdashery articles.

loans.name: Ayihonsi

texts.fr: D. Ayihonsi est née en 1964 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Ayihonsi vit à Agblangandan, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis 10 ans environs. Mariée à HOUNKPEVI Marcelin, un chauffeur, Ayihonsi est mère de six enfants, tous scolarisés. Ayihonsi vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Ayihonsi a fréquenté l’école jusqu’au cours secondaire. Il y a une dizaine d’année que Ayihonsi vend des divers (amuses gueule, liqueurs, lait, etc.) de façon ambulante. Ayihonsi s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Ayihonsi a obtenu une fois déjà, de crédit à ALIDé, et l’a bien remboursé. Ayihonsi sollicite un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé, en vue de renforcer son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
D. Ayihonsi was born in 1964 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin. Ayihonsi has lived in Agblangandan, in the Sèmè-Podji commune, for around 10 years. She is married to Hounkpevi Marcelin, a driver, and has six children who are all educated. Ayihonsi lives with her children and husband, and she and her husband take care of the family’s living expenses together. Ayihonsi did not complete high school.
Ayihonsi has worked as a street vendor selling various items (snacks, liqueurs, milk, etc.) for around 10 years. Ayihonsi stocks up at Dantokpa, the international market in Bénin.
Ayihonsi has already received and repaid a loan through Alidé. She is requesting a second Alidé loan to expand her business and to better satisfy her customers.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy snacks and liqueurs

loans.name: Gloria Maria

texts.es: Doña Gloria Maria se dedica ala costura desde hace varios años, tiene 50 años de edad, procreo cinco hijos, cuatro trabajan y el menor estudia, su esposo trabaja en una imprenta, gracias a la ayuda de su esposo inicio su negocio, luego con préstamo en Afodenic para la remodelación de su casa  que ha venido mejorando, con el crédito anterior pudo hacer un porche, y ahora trabaja en la costura el cual es fresco y con mas visibilidad para hacer los trabajo como para vista de los clientes, con este préstamo comprara materiales de construcción como: piedra, arena, cemento, hierro, y la compra de un inodoro para hacer el baño y el inodoro ya que lo que tiene es una letrina en el fondo del patio y esta forrado de zinc viejo el cual desea tener una mejor higiene para su familia y poder gozar de las mejoras. Sus planes es poder ayudar a su hijo menor para que termine su secundaria, a si como invertir mas en su negocio de costura.
texts.en:
Gloria Maria has been a seamstress for many years. She is 50 years old and has raised five children. Four of them work and the youngest is in school. Her husband works in a press shop and thanks to his help she started her business.

With a loan from Afodenic she started renovating her house. With a previous loan she built a porch where she now works since its cooler and has more visibility to work and for the clients. With this loan she will buy building materials such as stone, sand, cement, iron and a toilet bowl. The toilet bowl is to build a bathroom since she currently has a latrine lined with old zinc in the backyard. She wants to provide better hygiene conditions for her family and to be able to enjoy the improvements.

Her plans are to be able to help her youngest son finish high school and to invest in her sewing business.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase stone, sand, cement, iron, a toilet bowl for the bathroom and install the bowl

loans.name: Jose

texts.es: José de 64 años, es un hombre muy emprendedor que comparte su vida con su esposa Sabina y sus hijos Aldo (17) y Fernando (11), en su casa que es propia.Junto con su compañera de toda la vida  trabaja  en un pequeño puesto en el mercado Villa Estela (uno de los más concurridos del Balneario de Ancón), su esposa se dedica a la venta de pollo, y José a la venta de condimentos, en el mismo sitio, pero usualmente la que permanece más tiempo en el negocio es Sabina, ya que él  debe trasladarse hasta el centro de la ciudad para comprar la mercadería al por mayor para venderla después en su puesto. A los dos  les gusta mucho su trabajo y son muy cordiales con el trato al cliente ,es por esta razón que tienen gran cantidad de demanda, de otro lado ambos  esperan seguir mejorando y en un futuro ampliar el negocio para comprar  más cantidad de mercadería para así llegar a satisfacer todas las necesidades de la clientela y mejorar los ingresos familiares.Es su sétimo crédito con  MFP y siempre han sido muy puntuales y responsables en cada pago.Con el dinero del préstamo abastecerán su negocio con mayor cantidad de mercadería entre  condimentos y pollos para de esta manera  aumentar sus ingresos económicos.
texts.en:
Jose a very enterprising 64 year old man who shares his life with his wife, Sabina, and his sons, Aldo (17) and Fernando (11). He and his life partner work in a small stall in the Villa Estrella marketplace (one of the most well-known in the Balneario de Ancon neighborhood). His wife sells chicken and he sells condiments in the same location, but Sabina spends more time working the business, since he needs to travel to the city center to buy merchandise to resell from their stall. They both like their work very much and they treat their customers very well. This is why they have so many requests from them. They both hope to continue to improve their lives and be able to expand their business and be able to buy greater quantities of merchandise to be able to satisfy all of their customers’ need and increase their income. This is their seventh loan through MFP and they have always been responsible and on time with their payments. They will use the money from this loan to stock their business with more merchandise, chicken and condiments, to be able to improve their income.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy food products for resale

loans.name: Daouda

texts.fr:
Monsieur S., habitant de Cité Lamy á Thies, est tellement passionné par son métier: l'élevage de moutons de race Ladoume.  Il explique que l'élevage est comme la collection d'art: la valeur d'un animal et de l'art sont toujours dans la beauté.  Les plus beaux moutons coutent plus d'un million FCFA (environs $2200). 
Il organise , avec un groupe d'éleveurs, une foire d'élevage régionale  á Thies tous les mois de Mai et explique qu' il a des clients partout au Sénégal.  Cependant, il sollicite un crédit de 200,000 FCFA pour completer son budget afin d'acheter un mouton.  A  présent, il a quatre moutons et voudrait élargir son enclos.  Marié et  père de cinq enfants, M. S. pense que le crédit pourrait l'aider á développer avec la reproduction son entreprise et avoir une forte augmentation de ses revenus.
texts.en:
Mr. S. lives in Cité Lamy, in Thies, and is very passionate about his work raising Ladoume sheep. He says that raising sheep is like collecting art: the value of a piece of art, as well as an animal, lies in its beauty. The most beautiful sheep cost over a million XOF (roughly $2,200).
He organizes, along with a group of sheep farmers, a regional farming fair each May in Thies. He says that he has clients all throughout Senegal. He is requesting a 200,000 XOF loan to help him buy a sheep. He currently has 4 sheep and would like to expand his pen.
He is married with 5 children. Mr. S. thinks this loan could help him expand his business and increase his revenue.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy a Ladoume sheep

loans.name: Bernadette

texts.fr: S. Bernadette est née en 1979 à Porto-Novo, capitale administrative du Bénin. Bernadette vit depuis 18 ans à Agblangandan, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji au Bénin. Bernadette est mariée à AMOUHOUE David, un chauffeur. Le couple n’a pas encore d’enfant. Bernadette vit seule et supporte seule ses charges. Bernadette n’a jamais fréquenté. Pour faire face à ses besoins, Bernadette vend des produits de soins (pâtes dentifrices, lait corporel, etc.) de façon ambulante. C’est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin que Bernadette fait ses achats. Bernadette a 4 ans d’expérience dans ce domaine, et est à son troisième crédit à ALIDé. Bernadette a bien remboursé les deux premiers crédits qu’elle a obtenus de ALIDé. Bernadette voudrait renforcer le stock de ses produits. Mais compte tenu du peu de moyens financiers dont elle dispose, Bernadette sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
S. Bernadette was born in 1979 in Porto-Novo, the administrative capital of Bénin. Bernadette has lived in Agblangandan, in the Sèmè-Podji commune, for 18 years. Bernadette is married to Amouhoue David, a driver, and they do not have any children yet. Bernadette lives on her own and supports herself. She never went to school.
Bernadette works as a street vendor selling personal care products (tooth paste, body lotion, etc.) to support herself. Bernadette gets her products at Dantokpa, Bénin’s international market. Bernadette has been in this business for 4 years and is on her third Alidé loan, having repaid her first two. Bernadette would like to expand her stock of products and, given that she has limited means at her disposal, she is seeking a third loan with Alidé.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy tooth paste, tooth brushes and body lotion

loans.name: Abdul R.

texts.en:
This gentle guy is a businessman in the township of Magburaka in northern Sierra Leone. His name is Abdul R. M.; he owns a video center (like a cinema but he uses 21 inch television and satellite dishes) to show European soccer matches. Soccer is a very popular sport here and with the fall of domestic soccer during the period of the Ten Year civil war, youths have resorted to watching European matches for a pastime.

The 36-year-old has been running this business for many years now. A native of Magburaka town, he has been able to attract a lot of customers to his video center. Thus, to meet the growing demand of his customers, Abdul R. M. wants a loan of SLL 1,200,000 to buy decoders and subscribe to Super Sport, Canal, and Show Time. In this way, this husband and father of four children will be able to show almost any soccer match played in Europe and other parts of the world.

loans.use: Buy decoders and subscribe to  Super Sport, Canal, and Show Time

loans.name: Nkwa Na Ehia Group

texts.en:
Joseph, age 30, owns and operates a corn mill shop. He is also a farmer. These are the main sources of income by which he supports his family. He is married and the father of six children who are currently pursuing education in senior, junior, and primary schools. He lives with his family in their own house in a farming community.

Joseph is the leader of a village trust bank group called “Nkwa na Ehia” (Pray for Life). The members are all traders and food vendors who support their families through these businesses. They want to use the loan to purchase stock in bulk to avoid costly price hikes and also to cut down on frequent travels. They are expecting to make higher profits this season, which will help them support their families and pay their children's school fees. Your support through this loan would help to enable them to grow their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase stock in bulk

loans.name: Daniel D.

texts.en: This is 55-year-old Daniel D. T., a petty trader in his hometown of Magburaka, in northern Sierra Leone. This entrepreneur and husband of twelve children sells consumable and non-consumable goods in Magburaka town. He has been doing business for many years now. With this loan, he intends buying soft drinks, biscuits, mints, sugar, chewing gum, etc. in order to expand his business.

loans.use: Buy soft drinks, biscuits, mints, sugar, chewing gum, etc. in order to expand his business

loans.name: Las Cumbeñitas (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal las Cumbeñitas esta formado por un grupo de hombres y mujeres que buscan mejores oportunidades para salir adelante con sus familias y entregarles un fututo digno, son oriundos de la parroquia Cumbe donde viven algunos de los socios y otros viven en diferentes localidades de la ciudad de Cuenca. En ésta localidad la mayor parte de su población se dedica a la agricultura.

La señora  Martha Ordóñez es socia activa de éste banco comunal, ella  vive  en la comunidad los Sauces en la parroquia Cumbe con su esposo que trabaja como albañil  y sus ocho hijos de  26, 24, 22, 19, 16, 14, 13, 6 años de  edad, de los cuales el primero, segundo y cuarto hijo ya trabajan y aportan con los gastos del hogar, su hijo de 22 años está casado y aún vive con ellos, sus hijos  pequeños aun son estudiantes del colegio Cumbre y la escuela Arsenio Ullaguari, nuestra socia tiene 50 años  y gracias al esfuerzo conyugal lograron construir su casa propia.

Martha se dedica a la crianza de animales como pollos, cuyes, cerdos  para la fiesta navideña esta es  una actividad que  realiza desde que era muy pequeña inculcada por sus padres y que ahora le permite generar ingresos  económicos para ayudar a mantener a su familia;  sus animales los comercializa en su comunidad o sale a la ciudad para venderlos.

Se encuentra en su segundo ciclo trabajando con  la fundación y fue incentiva a  formar parte de éste  banco por sus compañeros que ya eran miembros del  mismo, con el préstamo que realizó  va a  comprar más crías de pollos para su negocio e irlo incrementando poco a poco.

Su meta es llegar a tener un gran criadero de pollos.

Carmen Fernández es otra de las socias de éste banco, ella  vive en el sector Cristo del Consuelo en la urbe cuencana, Carmen tiene 30 años  y es madre soltera de dos  niños uno  9 años  y el otro de  7 meses, su primer hijo estudia en la escuela de la comunidad, sus hijos no son reconocidos por su padre por lo que  ella  sola los está sacando adelante, viven arrendado porque no tienen casa propia

Nuestra socia se encuentra en su segundo ciclo trabajando  con la fundación y con el crédito anterior  adquirió  frutas para su negocio, nos comenta que siempre se ha dedicado a esta actividad  porque ayudaba a su mamá desde muy pequeña y ahora  ella se hizo cargo del negocio  para mantener a sus hijos;  con el nuevo  préstamo  solicitado va a comprar naranjas, manzanas, uvas, mangos y  mas frutas para incrementar su negocio y ofrecer variedad a sus clientes.

Su meta es ver a sus hijos crecer y que lleguen a ser buenos profesionales.
texts.en:
The Cumbeñitas Community Bank is formed by a group of men and women who search for better opportunities to provide for their families and to offer them a better future. They are from the Cumbe parish, where some of the members live. Others live in different locations in Cuenca. Most people in town is dedicated to agriculture .

Martha is an active member of the bank. She lives in the Sauces community, in the Cumbe parish with her husband who is a mason and their eight children ages 26, 24, 22, 19, 16, 14, 13 and 6. The first, second and fourth sons already work and help with household expenses. Their 22 year old son is married and still live with them. Their youngest children are still students at the Cumbre High School and Arsenio Ullaguari school. Our member is 50 years old. Thanks to the couple's efforts they were able to build their own home.

Martha breeds animals such as chickens, guinea pigs and pigs for Christmas festivities. She has been in this activity since she was little and was taught by her parents. Now it allows her to generate income to help provide for her family. She sells her animals in her community and out of town.

She is in her second cycle working with the foundation and was encouraged to be part of this bank by her friends who were already members. With the loan she requested she will buy more chicks for her business and will keep it growing little by little.

Her goal is to have a big chicken hatchery.

Carmen is another of this bank's members. She lives in the Cristo del Consuelo sector in the Cuiencara area. Carmen is 30 years old and is the single mother of two sons, 9 years old and 7 months old. Her oldest goes to the community's school. Her sons were not recognized by their father and she supports them alone. She rents because she does not own a house.

Our member is in her second cycle working with the foundation. With her previous loan she purchase fruit for her business. She tells us that she has always been in this activity because she helped her mom when she was young. She took over the business to support her sons. With the new loan she will buy oranges, apples, grapes, mangoes and other fruit to increase her business and offer more variety to her customers.

Her goal is to see her sons grow and for them to be good professionals.

Translated from Spanish by Betyna Almeida-Covarrubias, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase chicks and fruits such as oranges, apples, grapes, mangoes, etc.

loans.name: Mamadou

texts.fr:
M. Mamadou D. sollicite un crédit de 200,000 FCFA pour profiter de la chute de prix des mouton après la grande fête de Tabaski.  La Tabaski (Eid aux pays arabes) est la fête du sacrifice et marque la fin du Hadji, le pèlerinage á la Mecque.  Chaque personne majeure et qui a les moyens doit sacrifier un mouton pour marquer la fête, et les marches du Sénégal sont inondé avec les moutons.  Mais, après le fête, il y aura beaucoup de bons moutons lesquels les vendeurs voudraient rapidement vendre.  
M. D. est le secrétaire du Greffe, le tribunal de premier justice, à Bambey, environs 100km de Dakar.  UIMCEC y a ouvrit une caisse en Juillet 2009 pour mieux servir les clients ruraux.  L'achat et la vente de moutons est une activité secondaire pour M. D., mais quelque chose très important pour lui.  Son père est un éleveur très connu, et il a enseigné a son fils le métier.  Avec les bénéfices de son “opération Tabaski”, M. D. voudrait aider son père pour s'approvisionner plus des moutons et satisfaire son clientèle à meme-temps.
texts.en:
Mr. Mamadou D. is requesting a 200,000 XOF loan to take advantage of the drop in the price of sheep following the Tabaski celebrations. Tabaski (the Eid in Arab countries) is the festival of sacrifice to mark the end of the Hajj, the pilgrimage to Mecca. Every person over the age of majority who has the means must sacrifice a sheep to observe the festival, and the markets in Senegal are inundated with sheep. Once the festival is over, the sheep vendors are looking for a quick sale.
Mr. D. is the secretary of the Greffe, the court of first instance in Bambey, some 100km from Dakar. UIMCEC opened up a branch there in July 2009 to better serve rural clients. Buying and selling sheep may only provide a supplemental income to Mr. D., but it is still very important to him. His father is a well-known sheep farmer, who taught him the profession. With the profits from “Operation Tabaski”, M. D. would like to supply his father with more sheep while also satisfying his own customers’ demands.

Translated from French by Carolyn McCaffrey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy sheep

loans.name: Yesu Nkoa Group

texts.en: Felicia is thirty-eight years old. She is a wife and a mother of two children who are currently in school. She is a petty trader who sells smoked fish and food items. Felicia is constrained by funds to run the business. She needs a loan to inject more working capital into her business to scale up progress. She is the leader of a village trust bank group called “Yesu Nkoa” (Jesus alone). All the members are engaged in trading. They work so hard to put food on the table of their households and also to support their kids in school. They believe the loan will help them to be more resourceful to purchase food ingredients and stock in bulk. In time, they will be better able to serve their customers. They believe your support would enable them to grow their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase food stuff and other stock.

loans.name: Cécile

texts.fr: A. Cécile est née en 1961 à Dassa dans les Collines au Bénin. Cécile s’est installée à Sèmè-Podji au Sud du Bénin, il y a environs 18 ans. Mariée à SALAKO Jean, un conducteur de taxi-moto, Cécile est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés. Cécile vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Cécile n’a jamais été à l’école. Il y a environs quatre ans que Cécile s’est mise à vendre de l’akassa (aliment local fait à base d’amidon de maïs) à son domicile. Cécile vend également du savon (Fanico, Popular, etc.) à son domicile. Cécile s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Cécile a déjà bénéficié de deux crédits à ALIDé, crédits qu’elle a bien remboursés. Cécile sollicite un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé, pour augmenter son capital et renforcer le stock de ses produits, afin de mieux répondre à la demande des clients.
texts.en:
A. Cécile was born in 1961 in Dassa, Collines County, Benin. She got situated in Sèmè-Podji in southern Benin eighteen years ago. Married to SALAKO Jean, a moto taxi driver, she is the mother of three children, who are all in school. She lives together with her children and husband. The couple is covering family expenses jointly. Cécile never attended school. Four years ago, she started selling akassa (a local food made with cornstarch) in her home. She also sells soap (Fanico, Popular, etc.) in her home. She stocks up from Dantokpa, the international market of Benin. She has already benefited from two loans from ALIDé that she repaid. Cécile is requesting a third loan from ALIDé to augment her working capital and to bolster her stock of goods, so as to respond better to customer demands.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buying ten sacks of corn

loans.name: Wonders Group

texts.en: Felicia is forty-five years old. She is married and the mother of five children who are currently pursuing education in senior, junior and primary schools. She lives with her family in their own house in a farming community. Felicia runs a stationery store and also sells clothing. She makes her income mainly from these businesses to support her family. She is the leader of a village trust bank group called Wonders. The members are all traders and food vendors who support their families through these businesses. They want to use the loan to purchase stock, in bulk, to avoid price hikes and also to cut down on frequent purchasing travel. They are expecting to make higher profits this season to help pay their kids school fees. Your support would enable them grow their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase stock in bulk.

loans.name: Bineta

texts.fr: Mdm. Bineta B., l'age 42, travail au Agence de Santé Communicatrice à Bambey, une communauté rurale environs 100km vers l'est du Dakar.  UIMCEC y a ouvrit une caisse en Juillet 2009 pour mieux servir les clients ruraux.  Son activité secondaire est le commerce, et elle sollicite un crédit de 150,000 FCFA pour acheter des chaussures en gros pour les revendre à sa clientèle.  Sa soeur lui a fait aimer le commerce quand elle lui envoyait pour chercher les marchandises.  Mdm. B. se satisfait par l'autonomie fianciere du métier.  Elle est mariée et la mère de quatre enfants, entre les ages de 2 et 18 ans.
texts.en:
Ms. Bienta B., aged 42, works at the Agency of Health Communications in Bambey, a rural community about 100 km to the east of Dakar. UIMCEC (one of Kiva's field partners) started a loan fund in Bambey in July 2009 to better serve rural clients. Her secondary activity is commerce, and she is seeking a loan of 150,000 FCFA to buy shoes in bulk to re-sell to her customers. Her sister is responsible for her love of commerce, when the former sent her out to look for merchandise. Ms. B. is content with the financial autonomy of this job. She is married and has four children, who are between 2 and 18 years old.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To sell shoes

loans.name: Euphrasie

texts.fr: H. Euphrasie est née en 1957 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Mariée à HOUNKPATIN Toviessi, un forgeron, Euphrasie est mère de trois enfants. Certains enfants sont scolarisés. La famille vit ensemble à Agblangandan, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis trois ans. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. N’ayant jamais été à l’école, Euphrasie a commencé depuis environs 5 ans, la vente d’akassa (aliment local fait à base d’amidon de maïs), de façon ambulante. Euphrasie s’approvisionne à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. C’est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de trois crédits à ALIDé, crédits qui ont été bien remboursés. Euphrasie sollicite un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé, afin d’augmenter le stock de matière première (maïs), qui lui servira à produire suffisamment d’akassa, pour satisfaire toute sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Euphrasie H. was born in 1957 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. Married to Toviessi Hounkpatin, a blacksmith, Euphrasie is the mother of three children. Some of the children are in school. The family has lived together in Agblangandan, in the town of Sèmè-Podji, for three years. The couple provide for the family together. Never having gone to school, Euphrasie began selling akassa (a local food made from cornstarch) door-to-door about five years ago. Euphrasie gets her supplies at Dantokpa, the international market in Benin. She is a longstanding client of ALIDÉ (one of Kiva's field partners), having already benefited from three loans through ALIDÉ, all of which were repaid properly. Euphrasie is seeking a fourth loan through ALIDÉ in order to augment her stocks of raw material (maize), which will serve to produce enough akassa to satisfy all of her customers.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 50-kilogram bags of maize

loans.name: Las Triunfadoras Del Mañana (Cuenca) Group

texts.es:
El banco comunal Triunfadoras del Mañana se formó en la ciudad de Cuenca,  ciudad llena de tradiciones y  leyendas que encierra una belleza incomparable,  ésta urbe ha sabido aprovechar la riqueza de la zona en la que fue edificada elemento clave para su crecimiento económico y social que le ha llevado a ser una ciudad de gran empuje industrial.

Este banco está conformado por hombres y mujeres muy alegres  que se unieron impulsados a buscar una mejor calidad de vida para toda su familia,  nos brindan sus vivencias.

La señora María Alicia  C. es socia  activa de éste banco comunal  desde hace cuatro ciclos, vive en el sector El Carmen de Guzho  a unos 15 minutos fuera de la ciudad de Cuenca con sus cinco hijos de 13,12,6,5 y 2 años de edad, su hijo  mayor no estudia el prefiere trabajar y  lo hace  en una latonería mientras que sus hermanos estudian en la escuela Aurelio Ochoa y el bebe  pasa en una guardería. Gracias a su trabajo logró construir su casa propia.

María Alicia ingresó al banco comunal por incentivo de una amiga quien le hablo  de la facilidad de obtener los créditos y las facilidades de pago, ella se dedica a la venta de frutas desde hace quince años, no tiene un puesto propio por eso sus ventas las hace recorriendo todo el mercado esta actividad la realiza de domingo a domingo sin  descansar.

Nuestra socia nos comenta que con  los préstamos recibidos   ha  ido incrementando su negocio y con el nuevo crédito solicitado va a comprar más frutas como papaya, sandia, melón, guineo, manzana, mangos etc.  Para contar con un stock surtido de frutas para ofrecer a sus clientes y  seguir incrementando su negocio.

Su sueño es hacer mejoras en su casa.

La señora  Margarita Jiménez es otra de las socias del banco comunal Triunfadoras del Mañana, vive en la urbe de la ciudad de Cuenca, se encuentra en su cuarto ciclo y nos comenta que su hermana le incentivo a formar parte de la banca comunal, los prestamos le han beneficiado para seguir con su negocio.

 Margarita se dedica a la venta de legumbres trabaja en este negocio desde que era muy pequeña ya que su abuela y su mamá vendían en el mercado y dice que se podría decir que es una tradición familiar, esta actividad la realiza los  días jueves, sábados y domingos los demás días se dedica a cultivar la tierra.

Con el nuevo préstamo que reciba de la fundación va comprar   tomate, cebolla, arveja, zanahoria y más, para incrementar su negocio. Su meta es seguir creciendo en su negocio.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Triunfadoras del Mañana” (Tomorrow’s Winners) was founded in the city of Cuenca, which is surrounded by incomparable beauty and full of traditions and legends. The city has taken advantage of the abundance in the area, which has been a key to its economic and social growth that spurred its rise to becoming a high-powered industrial city.

This Communal Bank is composed of enthusiastic men and women who have joined together to seek a better quality of life for their families. They share their experiences with us.

Sra. María Alicia C. has been active member of this Communal Bank for the past four loan cycles. She lives in the area called El Carmen de Guzha, which is about 15 minutes away from the city of Cuenca, with her children ranging in age from 2 to 13 years. Her oldest child is not in school and preferred to pursue a job working at a brass works shop. The other school-age children attend classes at Aurelio Ochoa Elementary, while the baby is enrolled in day care. As a result of her work, María Alicia has managed to build her own home.

She joined the Communal Bank upon the recommendation of a friend who told her about how it easy it was to obtain loans and make repayments. María Alicia has been selling fruit for fifteen years. She does not have an established place for selling her goods, so she travels through the market offering her products every day without resting. María Alicia tells us that the loans have helped her increase her business and will use this new loan to buy more fruits such as papaya, watermelon, honeydews, bananas, apples, mangos, and other products to increase her assortment of stock to offer her to her customers, thereby generating more business. She dreams of making home improvements.

Sra. Margarita Jiménez is another member of the Tomorrow’s Winners Communal Bank. She lives in the city of Cuenca and is participating in her fourth loan cycle. Her sister invited her to become a member of the group and the loans have enabled her business to continue.

Margarita sells vegetables and has been in this business since she was a young girl because her grandmother and mother sold vegetables in the market. She continues the family tradition by selling produce on Thursdays, Saturdays, and Sundays. She is devoted to farming during the rest of the week.
