She has successfully repaid a previous loan from PMPC. Merlyn is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be her 11th from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About PMPC: Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Haydee

texts.en:
Haydee is a 43-year-old farmer in South Cotabato. She has been farming rice since 2007. She now manages a four-hectare rice field. She devotes most of her time in the field to improving her crops. She is the mother of six children and works hard to be able to feed her family.

Haydee is requesting a loan of 15,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to purchase farm supplies. This loan would be very useful to her, as it charges a low interest rate.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Meas

texts.en: Meas S., 54, is married and lives with his five children and wife in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. To make a living, he operates his car as a taxi driver. He usually gets his customers from a local market in the city. His wife is a good housewife and stays at home to look after their children. S. and his family members are seeking to improve their standards of living and generate a better income. Therefore, S. is asking for a loan of US $500 to repair his car. This is his first loan from CREDIT MFI, Kiva’s partner. In the future, he hopes he will be able to build a new and nice house for his family, as well as send his children to good schools.

loans.use: To repair his car

loans.name: Janette

texts.en:
Janette is a 42-year-old mother of three children. She has a rice farming business. It has been a decade since she entered into this business. She manages a 1¼ hectare rice field in South Cotabato.

She joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc. in order to sustain her business. She has now requested a loan of 15,000 PHP to purchase farm supplies.

Her earnings will be enough meet her family's daily needs and have savings.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies

loans.name: Sin

texts.en: Sin S., 41, is a humble mother of four teenage kids. One of her daughters helps cover the family’s expenses by working in the  garment industry. To makes a living, Sin S. owns and operates a small business selling groceries from home. Another income is from her husband’s climbing business. He also turns palm juice into palm wine or palm sugar for sale. The family also plants rice to supply food for themselves. Sin S. recently planted rice but it is not growing well due to the lack of fertilizer. Because of that obstacle, Sin S. is looking for a loan to purchase fertilizer to increase her crop yield.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
A resident of Dimalco, Bonifacio, Mrs. Delia P. is 45 years old, married and blessed with 2 school-aged children. Her husband Ruben owns and drives a motorcycle, known locally as a "jabal-jabal" for hire. Because of the economic crisis, Mrs. P. decided to start her own business, so she opened a "sari-sari" (variety) store in front of their house 6 years ago. She now earns an average net income of at least PHP 3,000 a month from her business. 

Delia joined PMPC this year because she was interested in the services and products offered. For Delia's first loan,she is borrowing PHP 3,000. She plans to add capital to her existing sari-sari store. Delia hopes that some day all her children will become successful, particularly in the pursuit of their education.

loans.use: Additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Mrs. Sarem Pech Village Bank Group

texts.en: Eight people who are all living in Trakiet village in Takeo province make up this village bank loan. Mrs. Sarem P. is the village bank president who has been selected by the members and they will each use the loan for different purposes. She is a farmer who owns a small piece of land on which she cultivates rice. Aside from this plantation, she is a palm juice middle woman, both buying and selling. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more palm juice to resell to earn more income. Her husband, Mr. Suong Soeung, is a construction foreman. Mrs. Sarem P. is 25 years old and the mother of two children who are too young to work or study.

loans.use: to buy more palm juice to resell

loans.name: Kim

texts.en: Kim Sreymach, 26, is married and lives with a school-aged child and her husband in Phnom Penh City, Cambodia. She is engaged in the agriculture sector  growing morning glory plants, earning a gross income of US $14 per day. Her husband is employed as a construction worker, earning an income of US $4 per day to help cover the family expenses. Kim and her family members are seeking to improve their standard of living and generate a better income. Therefore, Kim is asking for a loan of US $1200 to purchase morning glory seeds to expand her farming. She hopes that this loan to invest in her farming will help her family to generate more income and to save more money for the future of the child. This is her first loan from CREDIT MFI, Kiva’s partner.

loans.use: To buy morning glory seeds

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily Cervas is 38 years old and a corn farmer. She has four children. Her eldest is 18 years old and was not able to go to college because the family has financial difficulties. Enrolling her child in college was postponed because of their limited budget.

Emily would like to expand her business. She is applying for a loan of 8,000 PHP from the Kiva field partner, Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies, and this will augment her income toward enabling her to send her children to school.

loans.use: farm supplies

loans.name: Yolanda

texts.en:
Yolanda M., 58, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. Married to Faustino Iglesia, a carpenter, they are blessed with two children who are now working. She makes sure that she helps her husband by managing their own variety store. Aside from managing a store, Yolanda also has a food stand where she sells breakfast and other food viands. She has been in the variety store business for 16 years.

Yolanda has been a member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than five years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow ten times in CCT’s Cooperative.  The reason why she has been consistent in paying her dues is because she used almost all the money she borrowed as added capital for business purposes.  Her business now lets her earn a profit of PHP 5,200 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be mostly used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying more food and basic commodities like assorted snacks and beverages for her store.

She dreams that she can save enough money so that she can fix her house and finance her grandchildren's college education someday. 


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy more food and basic commodities like assorted snacks and beverages for her store.

loans.name: Enriquita

texts.en:
Enriquita C. is 65 years old and a client of the Kiva field partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She is a farmer from Banga, South Cotabato in Mindanao. She manages a small parcel of land on which she grows corn, which she hopes will provide her family adequate supplies of food, clothing and other basic needs. 

She is hoping to receive a loan of 10,000 PHP from CEVI. She will use the loan to buy the needed farm supplies to increase the size of her harvest and her income.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Jerry

texts.en:
Jerry P., 37 years old, is the father of two children. He is also a farmer and grows corn in Banga, South Cotabato Mindanao. Currently, he tills a 1-hectare corn field. His farm is doing well and he wants to make it more productive to augment his income.

He needs additional capital for his business. He is requesting a loan of 10,000 PHP from the Kiva field partner, Community Economic Ventures Inc. He will use the loan to buy farm supplies. He will also pay the laborers who helped him prepare the soil before planting.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia M., 58 years old, is a rice farmer. She is also a snack vendor in the schools. She said she earns much money by selling food in schools. The income she gets from her businesses is helpful in buying her family adequate food, clothing and other basic needs. She is looking for other means to augment her income. She admitted that she needs additional money to support her farm.

She would like to request a loan of 8,000 PHP from the Kiva field partner, Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies to improve her harvest and her income as well. She likes the CEVI program because it charges only 2% interest.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Merna C., who is 58 years old, owns a farm. She grows rice so that she will be able to help her family buy food, clothing and other basic needs. She also said she has been a farmer since she was born. Her parents are farmers, and all of her life has been spent on a farm. 

She would like to grow her business. She needs additional capitalization and requests a loan of 8,000 PHP from the Kiva field partner, Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She plans to buy farm supplies so that she will be assured of a quality harvest and a good income. The loan will truly help her expand her business as well.

loans.use: Farm supplies

loans.name: Doem

texts.en: Doem I. is 50 years of age and is currently a resident of Kampong Chhnang province, located about nineteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. She has built a pigpen next to her house, in which she raises pigs for a living. Doem I. has been married for many years to Dol Rady, and they have five children. One of them is married and lives independently and the others are single. Currently two grown sons are workers in the shoe producing industry. Doem I. also depends on the income from her husband who provides a battery charging service. Doem I. is taking out her loan to buy a used motorcycle, which she will use to make family transportation easier.

loans.use: To buy a used motorcycle

loans.name: Anecita

texts.en:
A widow and the mother of five children is Mrs. Anecita P. (pictured in a colored shirt with a customer), 66 years of age and a resident of Bintana, Tangub City.

Anecita is engaged in a sari-sari (variety) store business to support herself and her family. She started this business ten years ago and she has been able to sustain this business even in times of economic crisis. Now she is earning an average net income of not less than 2,500 PHP per month. She is also receiving support from her children who are already working.

Anecita joined Paglaum MPC just a year ago because she is very much interested in our products and services and for our being one of the most outstanding cooperatives in Northern Mindanao and the awarded coop for being “Most Outstanding Cooperative in the Philippines” during the search for the COOP-LGU Partnership Award, 2006.

As member of the PDP-LP (Paglaum Development Program for Landless People) Program, Anecita was able to obtain multiple loans because of her outstanding credit record. This time she is given the privilege of obtaining 12,000 PHP as her 4th loan to add to the capital of her sari-sari store business.

Anecita is hoping that someday her business will become a mini grocery store.

loans.use: To use as additional capital for her sari-sari store

loans.name: Emily

texts.en:
Emily D., 41, is striving hard so that she can have her sandal making business be at the same level as it was before.  Her business was badly affected when Typhoon Ketsana struck Metro Manila last September living their home flooded with water.   Married to Angelito D., they are blessed with four children. Together, she and her husband strive hard to manage their business so that their family can have a better life.  They have been selling sandals and slippers for eight years now.

Emily has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than three years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow seven times in CCT’s Cooperative.  The reason why she has been consistent in paying her dues is because she has used almost all the money she borrowed to buy raw materials for their sandal making business.  Their business now lets them earn a profit of PHP 5,200 per month.  

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a PHP 15,000 loan. This amount will be mostly used as a source of added capital by buying the raw materials needed for the expansion of their business.

Emily hopes that the extra profit that they will gain will let them save money so that they can finance their children's college education someday. 


* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy the raw materials needed for the expansion of their business.

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is a 53-year-old married farmer. He resides in Agusan Del Sur where farming is one of the major livelihoods. He cultivates his land for rice crops. James learned farming from his parents and now works on his own to earn a living for his family. He recently joined CEVI, an MFI in the Philippines, to gain access to its financial services. He requested a loan of 6,000 PHP, which he will use to finance his farm by purchasing farm supplies. This loan will help James sustain his farm and provide for his family.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Juliet

texts.en:
Juliet, 37 years old, is a married woman. She has four children and her oldest is 14 years old. Juliet is involved in rice farming. She works with her husband at the farm and still finds time to take care of her family. She wants to earn a better income to provide for the increasing needs of her family. She also wants all her children to have a proper education.

Juliet joined the Kiva field partner, CEVI, to have access to its program. She requested a loan of 6.000 PHP. She will use this loan to buy farm supplies, like seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Mirian

texts.en:
35-year-old Mirian is a married woman from Agusan Del Sur. She is involved in rice farming, which is the only source of income she currently has. At harvest time, she makes sure to set aside rice for her family, and sells the rest for income. She hopes to double up her harvest the next time so she can provide for her family’s growing needs.

Mirian is a member of the Kiva field partner, CEVI. She thinks that its program is very helpful to farmers like her, especially because of its low interest rate. She applied for a loan of 6,000 PHP. She will use this loan for farm supplies, such as seeds, fertilizers and many other things. This loan will help Mirian achieve an abundant harvest.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Sherlita

texts.en:
Sherlita, 42 years old, farms for a living. She has been married to her husband, Roger, for fifteen years. She has five children and the oldest is fourteen. She started farming ten years ago. Rice crops are what Sherlita plants on her land. She wants to maintain her business because it is her family's only source of income. Like any mother, she also wants all her children to finish school and find a decent job someday.

Sherlita recently joined the Kiva field partner, CEVI, to take advantage of its financial services. She says that her farm needs to be financed, but she lacks the money to do so. She applied for a loan of 6,000 PHP. This loan will be used for seeds, fertilizers and other farming necessities.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Leah

texts.en: Leah is a resident of Agusan Del Sur, where farming is one of the main livelihoods. She is 34 years old and grows rice on her farm. She inherited the farm from her parents. Leah wants to plant the best kind of seeds but admits that she lacks financially. She joined the Kiva field partner, CEVI, and applied for a loan of 6,000 PHP. She will use this loan to purchase quality seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies she needs. This loan will help Leah sell quality rice to people in her community.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en: 28-year-old Violeta is involved in rice farming. It is what she does to earn a living. She wants to earn more so that she could also save. She thinks it is very important to save in case an emergency occurs. She also wants her family’s living conditions to be improved. She joined the Kiva field partner, CEVI, to gain access to financial opportunities. She requested a loan of 6,000 PHP. She will use this loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farming necessities.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en: Sonia is a 39-year-old married woman. She has children who are of school age. She engaged in rice farming to earn an income for her family. She wants to earn more so she can save for her children’s future. Financially short, Sonia sought the help of the Kiva field partner, CEVI, a micro-finance institution in the Philippines. She applied for a loan of 6,000 PHP to finance her farm. With this loan, she will be able to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm supplies. She will also be able to pay the laborers who help at her farm.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Dennis

texts.en: Dennis, 25 years old, is a rice farmer. He learned farming from his parents and has been helping them till their farm since he was a teenager. He feels blessed to have a source of income. He works hard at the farm to sustain it and make it productive. He joined the Kiva field partner, CEVI, and applied for a loan of 6,000 PHP. He will use this loan for farm supplies like seeds, fertilizers and others. This loan will help Dennis’ farm be more productive.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Alicia

texts.en: 43-year-old Alicia has been married to her husband, Vicente, for twenty-one years. She has four children with him. Her oldest child is now 20.  Alicia engaged in rice farming sixteen years ago. She went through difficulties, but she feels blessed that her farm still exists and provides income for her family. She works hard to keep the farm healthy and productive. She also joined the Kiva field partner, CEVI, a micro-finance institution, to gain access to its financial services. She requested a loan of 6,000 PHP, which she will use to purchase the necessary farm supplies for her farm. This loan will help Alicia sustain her farm.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Chum

texts.en:
Chum C. is an older, widowed mother who has given birth to five children. One of her sons, who is shown in the picture, owns a small machine that he uses to mill rice and bran, which he then sells. He feeds any leftover rice to his pigs. 

Chum C. is 67 and lives in Kampong Chhnag Province where she owns a medium-sized farm. She earns a living from this land by growing a rice crop that she sells and eats. After Chum C. has harvested her rainy-season rice crop and collected the proceeds, she wants to replant a rice crop during the dry season. Due to the lack of capital, Chum C. would like to ask for a Kiva loan that she will buy use to buy fertilizer and seeds for her second crop.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and seeds

loans.name: Ma. Elena

texts.en: Ma. Elena is a 36-year-old woman from Agusan Del Sur. Like most of the residents there, she is involved in farming. She plants rice, which is one of the main agricultural crops there. She aims for an abundant harvest. Learning from her neighbors about the Kiva field partner, CEVI, she also joined to take advantage of its financial services. She saw that her neighbors' living conditions were improved, so she thought she could use the help as well. She applied for a loan of 6,000 PHP. With this loan, Elena will be able to finance her farm and purchase seeds and fertilizers.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Touch

texts.en:
Mrs. Touch B. is a villager in Royak village in Takeo province. She is a pig breeder. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing three more piglets for breeding, and she would use the rest of the loan to buy ten chickens for breeding. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions with this loan.

Her husband, Mr. Chea Sophoeun, is a farmer who owns a 1.5-hectare field of land for cultivating rice. Mrs. Touch B. is 44 years old and the mother of seven children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory while the others attend the local school. Her husband is shown in the picture with her.

loans.use: To buy three piglets and ten chickens

loans.name: Sao

texts.en: Mrs. Sao K. and her husband have been rice farmers for many years. This couple have been married for a long time and have four children. Two of their daughters are garment workers and are currently using their income to help their family. Rice comes to maturity at this time of year and Sao K. desires to have some extra income. She has decided to request a loan for capital to order mature rice in bulk to resell. (Sao K. was not available at the  time the photo was taken, and her husband appears instead.)

loans.use: To order mature rice for resale

loans.name: Eng

texts.en: Mr. Eng U. lives in Royak village in Takeo province. He is a farmer who owns a 2-hectare field of land where he cultivates rice to earn a living. He is a 60-year-old widower with three children who are employed in different positions. Mr. Eng U. is requesting a loan to add to his savings so that he can bU. a motorbike for his family.

loans.use: to buy a motorbike for his family

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary S. is 42 years old, married with a child. Her child is 15 years old and still dependent on her. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports the family. Mary is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. Mary sells firewood at retail prices to her customers to make a living. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. Mary is requesting for a loan amount of NGN 50,000 to purchase more firewood to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more firewood to sell

loans.name: Yein

texts.en:
Mrs. Yein P. is a villager in Niel village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a 4-hectare field of land on which she grows rice. On this farm, she faces an obstacle because she does not have enough money to buy rice seed or fertilizers, or to pay for the plowing of the land. In order to deal with this problem, she decided to ask for a loan.

Her husband, Mr. Norn Sam Oeurn, is a teacher in the local school. This couple has four children, two of whom are laborers and help with their mother’s work, and the others attend the local school. Her husband is shown on the photo with her.

loans.use: To buy rice seed & fertilizers, and to pay for the plowing of the land.

loans.name: Phan

texts.en: Phan S., age 22, is the mother of a young child  who is not yet enrolled in school. She has been earning a living as a crop cultivator. On the farm, her husband assists with her in growing crops.  Phan S. needs a loan to purchase oxen which she will use to help plow the land and to raise in the future.

loans.use: To purchase oxen

loans.name: Lola

texts.en:
Lola is 43 years old, married and has three children. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. Her husband makes a living selling medicines and works hard to help support his family. Lola is a LAPO client who sells cosmetics at retail prices to her customers. She loves this business because of the chance it gives her to have one-on-one interactions with people. She has applied for a loan for NGN 70,000 to buy more cosmetics to sell, and wants to extend her sincerest thanks to all Kiva lenders.  

LAPO (Lift above poverty organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and else where in Africa.

loans.use: To buy more cosmetics to sell

loans.name: Sumiat

texts.en:
Sumiat is 50 years old, married, and has four children. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. Her husband makes a living selling granite and sand, and works hard to support his family. Sumiat is a LAPO client who sells items made of plastic to her customers. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is requesting for a loan for NGN 70,000 to buy more plastic items to sell, and extends her sincerest thanks to all Kiva lenders.  
 
LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To buy more plastics to sell

loans.name: Toem

texts.en:
Mrs. Toem U. lives in Royak village in Takeo province. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Uk Hong, is a farmer who owns a plot of land for cultivating rice. Mrs. Toem U. needs some money to buy a cow for breeding, and she would use the rest of the money to buy more piglets and pig food for her pig-breeding business. She hopes to increase her income and improve her family's living conditions with this loan.

She is 51 years old and the mother of five children. One is employed in a garment factory, one is a beautician, two are farmers and the others are enrolled in the local school. Her husband is shown on the left in the photo.

loans.use: To buy a cow and more piglets and pig food

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario C., 49, works hard to provide for her family's daily needs. She is a widow with two children who runs three business: she manages a variety store, and sells milkfish and mobile phone prepaid credits. 

Rosario has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year. She regularly attends our weekly fellowship meetings and pays her dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with previous loans, she has been able to borrow money five times from our cooperative. The reason why she was consistent in paying her dues was because she used almost all of the money to buy more items to sell in her store. Her businesses earn her an incomoe of PHP 5,000 a month.  

Rosario has applied for a loan for a PHP 14,000 loan to buy milkfish and products to sell in her variety store. She dreams that her business will continue to grow and that her profits will increase so that she and her children can have a better life.  

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners who gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: to buy additional milkfish and other products to sell in her variety store.

loans.name: Kroch

texts.en: B. is a low-income farmer who lives in an area that is well-suited to growing crops. She is 57, married and has six children, one of whom is married and lives away from home. B. is very happy that three of her children have good jobs -- two work in the garment industry and one is a civil service officer. Her husband works for the ministry of religious affairs. B. will use this loan, her first, to buy a plot of good farmland, on which she will farm a variety of crops.

loans.use: To buy a plot of good farmland

loans.name: Ry

texts.en: Mrs. Ry A., a 48-year-old resident of Royak village in Takeo Province, owns a 1.8-hectare field upon which she cultivates rice to eA. for living. She is also a chicken breeder who is seeking a loan to expand her breeding business by purchasing more chickens, with the rest of money going toward the purchase of fertilizers to support her rice farming. Mrs. Ry A. is a widow with a married child who helps her with her businesses.

loans.use: To buy more chickens and fertilizers

loans.name: Folashade

texts.en:
Folashade is 45 years old, married and has four children. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. Her husband makes a living selling granite and sand, and works hard to support his family. Folashade is a LAPO client, and sells crates of eggs to earn additional  money. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with customers. She is requesting for a loan for NGN 70,000 to buy more crates of eggs to sell. She extends her sincerest thanks to all Kiva lenders for making this loan possible. 
 
LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To buy more crates of eggs to sell

loans.name: Gilda

texts.en:
Gilda R., 49 years old and married to a farmer, grows rice. She started tilling the farm in 1990, and in just three months her first harvest was 86 sacks of rice. She joined the CEVI credit program in 2008, actively participating in the CEVI cluster meetings together with other farmers. 

She now needs additional capitalization in her business and so is requesting a loan of Php 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies to increase her harvest and income.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Mon

texts.en: Mrs. Mon V. is a villager in Royak village in Takeo province. She is a pig breeder. Since her pig breeding business is doing well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets, pig food, and a cow for breeding. Her husband, Mr. Ek Puy, is a farmer who owns a plot of land and cultivates rice. Mrs. Mon V. is 50 years-old and the mother of four children, three of whom are employed in a garment factory while the fourth attends a local school. Her husband is in the picture with her.

loans.use: To purchase piglets, pig food, and a cow.

loans.name: Merly

texts.en:
Merly Nunez, 51 years-old, is a rice farmer from Norala South Cotabato. She said that her family relies very much on her farm. Whatever income she makes from it she uses for daily needs. She does not plan to stop farming until all her children graduate school.

She would like a loan of Php 8,000 from Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies. In that way, she will be able to increase her harvest and income.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: Dieynaba

texts.fr:
Madame Dieynaba N., agée de 51 ans, est une commerçante de légumes et poissons au marché principal de Bambey, une communauté rurale situé 100km de Dakar  UIMCEC y a ouvrit une caisse en Juillet 2009 pour mieux servir les clients ruraux.  Elle explique qu'elle a commencé le commerce en 1989, avec l'invitation de sa soeur.  Aujourd'hui, elle a son propre éventaire sous l'abris du marché.  Avec le crédit de 150,000 FCFA elle voudrait acheter des arachides, cubes Maggi (un épice) et des légumes verts.  
Madame N. est mariée et mère des enfants majeurs, mais elle est en charge de deux petits fils.
texts.en:
A 51 year-old woman, Dieynaba N. sells vegetables and fish at the main market of Bambey, a rural community located 100 km (60 miles) from Dakar. UIMCEC (one of Kiva's field partners) started a loan fund in Bambey in July 2009 to better serve rural clients. Mrs. N. started her business in 1989 at the suggestion of her sister. Now she has her own stand indoors at the market. With this 150 000 CFA francs loan she would like to buy peanuts, Maggi cubes (a spice) and green vegetables. Mrs. N. is married and has adult children, but she is responsible for two male grandchildren.


Translated from French by Joanne Archambault, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase food

loans.name: Myrna

texts.en:
Myrna D., 54 years-old is a mother and a farmer in Sta. Josefa Agusan del Sur. She has three adult children who help her on the farm tilling the soil. They work from morning until sunset so that they ensure an abundant harvest because they really take seriously the growing of their rice crop.

She is hoping to receive a loan of 8,000 from Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies. In that way she will be able to improve the size of her harvest and her income.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: Mean

texts.en: Mrs. Mean S. lives in Daeum Rumdael village in Takeo province. She is a pig breeder. Her husband, Mr. Kouy Sae, is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation, he is a traditional musician who is hired by villagers for wedding ceremonies. In his plantation, he faces difficulties because his field has infertile soil and a lot of insects which damage the rice crops. Therefore, Mrs. Mean S. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers, pesticides and to pay for ploughing the rice field. She is 53 years-old and the mother of five children, two of whom are employed in a garment factory, one who helps his parents work and the others attend the local school. Her husband is shown on the right of the photo.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer, pesticides and plough the rice field.

loans.name: Moruf

texts.en: Moruf is 30 years old and married with a child. He lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. His wife sells medicine to support the family. He is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. He sells phone accessories at retail prices to his customers to make a living. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He is requesting a loan of NGN 50,000 to purchase more phone accessories to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more phone accessories to sell

loans.name: Toem

texts.en: Toem Y. is 38 years old and a resident of Kampong Chhnang Province, Cambodia. She is a mother of three children. All three go to school or to work. She is married to Eang, 42, who relies on catching fish in and around the river. To earn a living, Toem Y. runs a small store out of her home where she has been selling groceries to her fellow neighbors throughout the commune since 2000. Toem Y. needs a loan to buy more groceries to sell and to buy more tools for fishing.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to sell

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
Nena P., 61 years-old, has a farm. Her main crop is rice because people in their village are constantly buying it for food for their respective families. She has four adult children who also help her grow rice. She dreams of improving her livelihood and trying to venture to other income opportunities when she has the capital.

She is asking for a loan of Php 8,000 from Kiva partner Community Economic Ventures Inc. The loan will go towards buying farm supplies to grow her harvest and income. She will also use some of the loan to start a new business.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. Chea V. is a villager in Pou Roung village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a piece of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation, she earns income as a fish seller in the local market. Since her business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more fish to resell to earn more income. Mrs. Chea V. is 36 years old and the mother of two children who are attending the local school.

loans.use: To purchase more fish to resell to earn more income

loans.name: Agbéko

texts.en: Ms. S. is a single woman who works selling a variety of cereals. She began her business in 1990 and lives in the Agoé region of Togo. This will be her first loan with WAGES, which she will use to restock her supply. She plans on purchasing one bag of corn and nine bags of beans. These purchases will help Ms. S. keep her customers satisfied.

loans.use: To buy corn and beans

loans.name: Srey

texts.en: Mrs. Srey O. is 48 years old and she lives in PO. Roung village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate both rice and vegetables. Now she needs some money to buy fertilizers to support her rice farming. Mrs. Srey O. is a widow with three children, one of whom sells rice soup and rice with pork; the others are attending the local school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers to support her rice farming

loans.name: Funmilola

texts.en: Funmilola is 46 years old, married and has four children. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. Her husband is a commercial driver and he also supports the family. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She sells cooking oil and eggs at retail prices to her customers to make a living. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is requesting a loan of NGN 150,000 to purchase more cooking oil and eggs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking oil and eggs to sell

loans.name: Khai

texts.en: Mrs. Khai C. is a villager in Chuos village in Takeo province. She is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice. Aside from this plantation, she earns income as a pig breeder. Since her pig breeding business is going well, she wants to expand it by purchasing more piglets and pig food for breeding. She hopes to increase her income and improve the family's living conditions with this loan. Mrs. Khai C. is 54 years old and the mother of a child who is employed in a garment factory.

loans.use: To purchase more piglets and pig food for breeding

loans.name: Afi Djigbodé

texts.en: Like many other Togolese entrepreneurs, Ms. A. engages in many activities to support herself and her two children. She sells fabrics for clothing as well as charcoal and firewood. She is divorced and lives and works in the Agoé region of Togo. This will be her first loan with WAGES, which she will divide between both her businesses. Specifically, she will purchase 20 bags of charcoal and 1 load of fabrics. This loan will help keep her two businesses running smoothly.

loans.use: To buy fabric and charcoal

loans.name: Patria

texts.en:
Patria A., 64 years old, is a farmer. She helps her husband till a 1 hectare farm producing quality rice to feed and clothe her family. She has been a farmer since 1998. The income she gets from the farm benefits her family a lot. It especially helps them pay for daily expenses in their home.

When Patria started farming, she also joined the CEVI credit program. She would like to request a loan of 11,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use this loan to buy farm supplies in order to have an abundant harvest.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Vaen

texts.en:
Mrs. Vaen N. is a farmer who owns a plot of land to cultivate rice for a living. Mrs. Vaen N. is 51 years old and the mother of nine children: four are construction workers, two others are vendors and the rest are attending the local school. Her husband, Mr. Muk Mun, is a palm juice collector. She is a villager in Ping Pong village in Takeo province.

Mrs. Vaen N. faces an obstacle with her plantation because she does not have enough moN. to buy farming supplies. Therefore, she decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizers and pesticides and to pay for plowing the rice field.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and pesticides and to pay for plowing the rice field

loans.name: Keut

texts.en: From day to day, Mrs. Keut R. and her family weave bamboo baskets to sell. She is 46, married and has eight children. Two of the children are employed in Phnom Penh and the others are jobless. In addition, her husband built a small workshop in which he provides a bicycle repair service. He also weaves baskets when he is free from his job. (Keut R. was not available when the photo taken so her husband is pictured instead.) Keut R. will be using the loan to buy her nearby neighbor’s house to tear down and use to enlarge/redecorate her existing house.

loans.use: To buy a nearby neighbor’s house

loans.name: Moruf

texts.en: Moruf is 35 years old and married with three children. He lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. His wife sells groceries and she also supports the family. He is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. He sells batteries at retail prices to his customers to make a living. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more batteries to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more batteries to sell

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario Q. is a 55-year-old woman from Norala, South Cotabato. She has a farm and rice is her main crop. She started farming in 1950 and continues to farm as it is her only source of livelihood. She has five married children.

Rosario is applying for a loan of 12,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies to ensure that her plants are well taken care of. She also hopes that the loan will bring her a better harvest and income.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Ibtisam

texts.en:
Ibtisam is a Palestinian married woman, her family consisting of seven members. Two of her adult children are working in the Palestinian National Authority and their incomes, in addition to Ibtisam’s business income, form the main source of income for the family.

Ibtisam’s business is selling used clothes and clothes that are new but are out of fashion (after the shops put clearance on their product then the remaining products are sold wholesale to special merchants who sell them in developing countries). In addition to clothes she also sells used electronic equipment - in general she sells everything that is used or out of fashion. The business was established fifteen years ago and is managed by Ibtisam and her husband.

Ibtisam is one of FATEN’s first clients in its Bethlehem branch. She started with 200 USD and took several loans and repaid them all on time and fully. She always asks for small loans that suit her business size and her ability to repay. Currently she requested from FATEN 300 Jordanian Dinar and wants to use the loan to buy some products for her business for the winter season.

Ibtisam appears in the photo at her business with some used electronic equipment.

loans.use: To buy some products for her business for the winter season

loans.name: Midou

texts.en:
Midou A. is the divorced mother of three children. She works selling fabrics for clothing in the Kégué region of Lomé. She has approached WAGES for her first loan, which will be used to resupply her stock. She will purchase a variety of fabrics from popular brands such as HiTarget and Phoenix.

This loan will help Ms. A. support both her business and her family.

loans.use: To buy fabrics that will be used to make and sell clothing

loans.name: Olubumi

texts.en: Olubumi Y. is 45 years old and married with 3 children. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. Her husband sells medicines and she also supports the family. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. Olubumi sells cooking oil and eggs at retail prices to her customers to make a living. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. Olubumi is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more cooking oil and eggs to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more cooking oil and eggs to sell

loans.name: Uong

texts.en:
Mr. Uong K. is a villager in the village of Kampao in the province of Takeo. He is a farmer who owns a plot of land, which he uses to cultivate rice. He is 63 years old and is a widower with two children: the eldest is a vendor of general grocery products and the younger helps his father in the field.

Since his older child’s general-store business is going well, Mr. K. wants to help expand it and make it more profitable. He will use this loan to purchase more products to sell so that the store can bring in more income and help support the family.

loans.use: By purchasing more grocery items for sale

loans.name: Ndeye Fatou

texts.fr:
Madame Ndeye Fatou M., agée de 35 ans, est une commerçante de produits divers à Bambey, une communauté rurale situé à 100km de Dakar.  UIMCEC y a ouvrit une caisse en Juillet 2009 pour mieux servir les clients ruraux.  Elle sollicite le crédit de 100,000 FCFA pour acheter une stock de chemises de nuit, vetements féminines, chaussures et produits lessives.  
Elle est une commerçante pour 10 ans, grâce á sa belle mère qui l'a initiée.  Madame M. explique le travail n'est pas trop fatigant et sa permet de gagner sa vie aisément  Elle vend sur place dans le marché de Bambey.  Elle est mariée et mère de deux enfants, agés de quatre et six ans.
texts.en:
A 35 year-old woman, Ndeye Fatou M. sells various products in Bambey, a rural community located 100 km (60 miles) from Dakar. UIMCEC (one of Kiva's field partners) started a loan fund in Bambey in July 2009 to better serve rural clients. She is requesting a 100 000 CFA francs loan to buy a supply of nightgowns, clothing for women, footwear and laundry detergent. Her mother-in-law got her started in this business ten years ago. Mrs. M. says that the work is not too tiring and that it allows her to easily make a living. She is married and has two children, ages 4 and 6.


Translated from French by Joanne Archambault, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase clothing

loans.name: Ndeye Nogaye

texts.fr:
Madame Ndeye Nogaye M. sollicite son premier crédit, pour un montant de 100,000 FCFA.  Elle vend de tissus et chaussures à sa communauté de Bambey, situé 100km de Dakar.  UIMCEC y a ouvrit une caisse en Juillet 2009 pour mieux servir les clients ruraux.  
Elle appris le commerce dès l'age très jeune et, elle explique, qu'elle trouve généralement la commande dans leurs association de femmes sans en demarcher.
texts.en:
Mrs. Ndeye Nogaye M. is requesting her first-ever loan in the amount of 100 000 CFA francs. She sells fabric and footwear to her community in Bambey, located 100 km (60 miles) from Dakar. UIMCEC (one of Kiva's field partners) started a loan fund in Bambey in July 2009 to better serve rural clients. She learned this business at a young age. She says that she usually gets her orders from the women’s association without having to sell door to door.


Translated from French by Joanne Archambault, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fabric and footwear

loans.name: Un

texts.en: Un S., 28, is a single woman living with her old mother in Kampong Chhnang province. She is the oldest of the three siblings. To earn a living, Un plants rice and vegetable crops for selling. To help meet the needs of the family, her second sister works sewing clothes for industry. Un S. requests a loan to purchase piglets to breed, as well as to buy a bicycle to help with transportation.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to breed

loans.name: Romoke

texts.en: Romoke T. is 40 years old and  married with 4 children. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. Her husband is a civil servant who also supports the family. Romoke is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. Romoke sells groceries at retail prices to her customers to make a living. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is requesting for a loan of NGN 70,000 to purchase more groceries to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more groceries to sell

loans.name: Julieta

texts.en:
Julieta A., 38, is eager and excited with her business of buy and selling cosmetics and other skin care products. Married to Nolito A., a laborer in a private company, they are blessed with two children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life.  

Julieta has been a regular member of Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than a year now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow four times in CCT’s Cooperative.  The reason why she was consistent in paying her dues was because she used almost all the money she borrowed in buying different cosmetic products for her business.   Her business now lets her earn PHP 3,500 per month.  

Now with your help, Julieta would like to apply for a PHP 10,000 loan. This amount will be mostly used as a source of added capital to her expanding business by buying additional cosmetic products like powder, lotions, deodorant and the like.

She prays that she and her husband can have enough resources so that her children can finish their studies in college.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy additional cosmetic products like powder, lotions, deodorant and the like.

loans.name: Bosede

texts.en: Bosede B. is 41years old, married with 5 children. The family lives in Oyo State. Bosede produces and sells polythene bags. She has been in this trade for over 17years. Bosede is requesting for a loan of N100,000 to purchase material for the production of polythene bags. This loan will reduce basic costs, costs of transportation to market and increase profits.  She will be able to serve her clients better and this also will better help her in caring for her family. Bosede says thank you to all lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more material for production of polythene bag to sell

loans.name: Rosario

texts.en:
Rosario L., 51 years old, started tilling her farm in 1990. Her primary crop is rice, but she also plants vegetables in her farm. She really enjoys farming. She tells us that her life is really in the farm that she tills, and she is happy when it succeeds and she harvests the grains. Currently, she is busy preparing the soil to get ready for planting rice seedlings.

She will need additional capital in order to ensure the success of her business. For this reason, she is asking for a loan of Php 6,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc., which she will use to buy all the farm supplies she needs to grow her crop. This loan will really help in ensuring that Rosario will experience a quality harvest.

loans.use: Essential farming supplies

loans.name: Denis

texts.en:
Denis O. O. is 28 years old. He is married and has 2 children who are in school.

His business is situated in Kariobangi-Nairobi where he is a tailor, mainly making men's suits and trousers. Denis' customers are locals. He hopes to expand his business and become a big distributor of suits. His major challenges are the rise in prices of materials and the competition he faces. Many people in the area engage in the same kind of business.

Now, Denis is purchasing more materials to grow his business. He is hardworking and focused. He is requesting a loan to support these improvements and his business.

loans.use: Materials for making men's suits and trousers

loans.name: Maye

texts.fr: Madame Maye F. est une commerçante à Bambey, une communauté rurale située à 100km de Dakar.  UIMCEC y a ouvrit une caisse en Juillet 2009 pour mieux servir les clients ruraux.  Elle a pratiqué le commerce grâce à ses amis qui faisaient aussi du commerce  Par rapport aux aspects les plus importants de son métier, Madame F. identifie surtout la connaissance humaine.  Elle sollicite son premier crédit pour acheter de boubous bazins et des chaussures.  Madame F. est mariée et mère d'enfants majeurs.
texts.en:
Mrs. Maye F. is a merchant in Bambey, a rural community located 100 km from Dakar. UIMCEC (Kiva Field Partner) first opened its doors in July 2009 to better serve rural clients. She started as a merchant because her friends also were merchants. Mrs. F. indicates that the most important aspects of her business is by knowing human nature. She is requesting her first loan and she will use it to purchase boubous (loose flowing gowns) and shoes. Mrs. F. is married and is the mother of grown children.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase clothing and shoes.

loans.name: Ruby

texts.en:
Ruby R., 32 years old, is a rice farmer. The eldest of her two children is 12 years old and currently in elementary school. Ruby reports that she started her business in 1992, but did not yet have her own farm. Five years later, she was able to buy her own farm, where she now cultivates rice.

She would like to request a loan of Php 15,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. This loan will allow her to purchase essential farm supplies. She is also looking for some other income opportunities in order to augment her family's income. Receiving this loan will help bring her closer to getting started in a new business venture as well as ensuring a quality rice harvest.

loans.use: To buy farming supplies

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth S., age 32, is a rice farmer. She owns a small rice field, which provides her with a modest income, allowing her to support her family with an adequate supply of food, clothing, and other basic provisions. Her rice farm is doing well at present, and she hopes it will continue to yield an abundant harvest so that she can continue to meet the needs of her family. She has been married since 1999.

She is asking for a loan in the amount of Php 12,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She likes the CEVI program because she is covered with a micro insurance package. Her loan will be used to buy much-needed farm supplies to ensure a successful and ongoing harvest from her field.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Napo Mariama

texts.en:
Napo Mariam T. has 20 years of experience selling clothing and supplies for babies. She lives in the Agoé region of Togo, and works in the Agoé market. She is married and has six children.

This will be Mrs. T.'s first loan with WAGES, and it will be used to purchase children’s outfits and shoes in the Grand Marché to replenish her supply. This loan will help support her growing business and help her provide for her family.

loans.use: To buy baby clothes and shoes for sale

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth T. is a rice grower who tills a one-hectare farm. She has a 13-year-old child who helps her in the field. Ruth tells us that loans have been helping her family to buy the farm supplies they need to ensure a strong harvest. 
Ruth would like to request a loan of Php 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy farm supplies that will provide for a quality and abundant rice harvest. She is hoping for a good return investment from her loan and is doing her best to make her farm productive.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies

loans.name: Lukuman

texts.en:
Lukuman is 40 years old. He is married with 3 children. He is a focused and hardworking man and he is a member of LAPO.

He sells foodstuffs like yams and tomato seeds to earn a living. He has been in business for over 20 years. Lukuman's focus is to expand his business. He is also doing all he can to pull his family to a higher financial level.

One of Lukuman's greatest joys is the one-on-one interactions he is able to have with his customers.

Lukuman is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs, like yams and tomato seeds, to sell.

He says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs to sell

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en:
Nicholas M. is 29 years old. He is married and he has two children. His wife is still in school and they hope that their two children will get a good education some day.

His business is located in Gikomba-Nairobi, where he sells sofa set materials. Nicholas needs a loan to buy more stock for his business. He hopes that in the future, his business will be able to supply large quantities of materials, thereby satisfying his current customers and expanding his client base.

He is hardworking, smart and handsome.

loans.use: To purchase more materials for his business

loans.name: Rosalinda

texts.en:
Rosalinda P., 39, is making sure that her family has enough provisions for their daily needs. She is married to Wilfredo P., a driver. They are blessed with four children. She makes sure that she helps her husband earn so that their family can have a better life by managing their small piggery. She has been breeding and selling pigs for ten years.

Rosalinda has been a regular member of the Center for Community Transformation* (CCT) for more than three years now. She regularly attends their weekly fellowship meetings and pays her weekly dues consistently. Because of her good repayment performance with her previous loans, she was able to borrow six times from CCT’s cooperative. The reason why she was consistent in paying her dues was because she used almost all the money she borrowed to buy feed for her pigs. Her business lets her earn a profit of 30,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) per month.

Now with your help, she would like to apply for a loan of 18,000 PHP. She will use this amount as a source of added capital for her expanding business by buying more feed for her increasing number of pigs.

She dreams that she and her husband can save enough money so that her children will finish their studies and find their own career paths. * All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and make payments on microfinance loans.

loans.use: To buy feed for her increasing number of pigs

loans.name: Ayichétou

texts.en:
Ayichétou I. sells a variety of grocery products and jewelry in the Agoé region of Togo. She began her business in 2003. She is married and has two children.

Mrs. I. is requesting her first loan with WAGES. She will use the loan to purchase grocery products for sale - specifically, 10 bags of rice, 10 barrels of oil, three cases of tomatoes, one case of macaroni, and 10 cases of wine. This will increase and diversify the supply she is able to offer her customers.

loans.use: To purchase grocery products for sale

loans.name: Tomas

texts.en: Tomas, 33 years old, has a rice farming business. He is the father of three children, the eldest of whom is six years old. Tomas tills a one-and-a-half-hectare rice field to support his family. He lacks capital and has joined Community Economic Ventures, Inc., in order to request a loan. He has requested 15,000 Php to support his business. With the money he receives, he will buy farm supplies and fertilizers for his farm, ensuring a successful harvest. The loan has a low interest rate and is not burdensome to him.

loans.use: To fertilizers and farm supplies

loans.name: Chea

texts.en: Mrs. Chea S., 43, is a married woman who is blessed with three school-aged kids. They live together in a wooden house located in Pursat Province, where she owns a small piece of farm land on which she grows a variety of crops to earn a living. Mrs. Chea S. got married many years ago to Mr. Chomroeun, who is 41 years old and currently sells fresh fish that he buys in bulk from fishermen. Mrs. Chea S. has requested a loan to buy a used motorbike, which will allow to her husband to pick up more fish to bring to the market. (Mrs. Chea S. and her husband are pictured above.)

loans.use: To buy a used motorbike

loans.name: Rowenda

texts.en:
Rowenda, 35 yeas old, has been a rice farmer since 1986. At this point, she runs her own rice farming business, cultivating a one-and-a-half-hectare rice field in Banga, South Cotabato. She loves her work on her farm. As the mother of two children, she strives hard in order to provide for the basic needs of the family.

She has requested a loan of 8,000 from Community Economic Ventures, Inc., to support her work on her farm. With this amount, she will be able to buy seeds and essential farm supplies.

loans.use: To buy seeds and farm supplies

loans.name: Islomdjon

texts.en:
Islomdjon is married and has a little son. He and his family live in Khujand, Tajikistan. Islomdjon started his own small venture after his relatives suggested he should try his luck as a market vendor. Today Islomdjon runs a small business selling women’s clothing. His vending facility has a very favorable location and offers a large assortment of merchandise, which attracts many customers. Islomdjon believes that financial support from IMON International has helped him boost his sales and grow his business. He would like a loan of 6800 Somoni to purchase inventory wholesale. Islomdjon believes this loan will help him further develop his business and get additional income to improve his family’s living standards.  


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To increase his working capital.

loans.name: Soutoura Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Soutoura comprend 4 femmes mariées, dans des ménages monogames, qui ont en moyenne 38 ans et 4 enfants. Elles habitent dans le quartier Pelengana Sud de la ville de Ségou (4ème Région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de mariage et professionnel. 
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers (produits de beauté, pagnes, encens, tissus brodés, chaussures en plastique etc.)
C’est dans le souci de satisfaire leur clientèle qu’elles ont décidé d’intégrer le  programme  crédit  de l’institution de microfinance  Soro Yiriwaso avec qui  elles sont à leur 3ème prêt solidaire après avoir  remboursé les deux précédents. 
Ce nouveau prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 3 pièces de pagnes wax, 5 tenues de tissus brodés, une soixantaine de boites de crèmes et pommades pour la peau et les cheveux, 25 kg de « gueni » 3 flacons d’eau de Cologne, 10 flacons de parfums et 24 flacons vides où mettre de l’encens pour la vente. 
Elles s’approvisionnent en tenues de tissus brodés au Burkina Faso, en pagnes wax,  ingrédients pour la préparation de l’encens au grand marché de Ségou, les crèmes et pommades sont achetées à Bamako.         
Pour faire son encens elle pile légèrement le « gueni » puis le trie et le submerge dans l’eau de Cologne dans un vase qu’elle ferme hermétiquement durant un mois, après elle y ajoute une quantité suffisante de parfums , bien mélanger avant de le mettre dans les boites pour la vente.  
Les habits sont revendus à Dioro, Markala et à Ségou ville, les crèmes, les pommades et l’encens sont revendus à domicile et en ambulant  dans le quartier. 
Les ventes se font généralement au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femmes. 
Elles espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 21.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement du prêt de Soro Yiriwaso, la participation aux évènements sociaux (mariages, baptêmes, circoncisions et funérailles), l’épargne et  la contribution dans la prise en charges de certaines dépenses familiales.
Leur ambition d’aller à l’individuel et devenir des grossistes.
texts.en:
The Soutoura group comprises 4 married women who live in monogamous households and are, on average, 38 years old with 4 children. They live in the South Pelengana area of the city of Ségou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They know each other through marriage, community, and professional relations. This group of women runs businesses selling various items (cosmetics, pagnes - a type of brightly-printed West African cloth, incense, embroidered fabric, plastic footwear, etc.) It is with the hope of satisfying their clientele that they decided to join the loan program of the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso (one of Kiva's field partners), with whom they are on their 3rd solidarity (group) loan, after having repaid their two previous loans. This new loan will be used to buy 3 sets of pagnes wax, 5 sets of embroidered clothing, 60 boxes of creams and ointments for skin and hair, 25 kg of "gueni" (a fragrant root), 3 bottles of eau de Cologne, 10 bottles of perfume, and 24 empty bottles in which to put incense for sale. They get their supplies of embroidered clothing in Burkina Faso,their pagnes wax and ingredients to prepare incense at the grand market in Ségou, and buy their creams and ointments in Bamako. To make their incense, they lightly grind the "gueni", then hand-pick and submerge it in eau de Cologne in a vase that they seal hermetically for a month, after which time they add a sufficient quantity of perfume and mix it well before putting it in boxes for sale. The clothes are re-sold in Dioro, Markala, and the city of Ségou, while the creams, ointments, and incense are re-sold at home or door-to-door in the area. The sales are generally made in cash and on credit to a clientele composed of men and women. They hope to realize an average monthly profit of 21,000 FCFA, which will be used to repay the loan from Soro Yiriwaso, provide for social and family occasions (marriages, baptisms, circumcisions, and funerals), increase savings, and take care of certain family expenses. Their ambition is to own individual businesses and become wholesalers.

Translated from French by Vilas Menon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing, cosmetics, and ingredients to make incense

loans.name: Lando

texts.en:
Like many enterprising women in Africa, Ms. Lando F. doesn't just sell one thing. If she can buy something low and sell it for a bit higher, she will take it on. Currently, she sells oranges at the main market in Bambey. She began her trade in 2000, when a younger brother lent her money to buy her first stock. She enjoys the daily interactions with clients and other vendors at the market, and of course the profits she can make. She is married and the mother of six children.

UIMCEC opened a branch in the area in July of this year to better serve rural clients. With her loan of 150,000 FCFA, Ms. F. would like to purchase incense, perfumes, and thioub (a kind of traditional dress) to sell to other women in the community. She hopes the credit will increase her income enough to support her family and to help send her son to a private high school.

loans.use: To buy perfume and clothing for sale

loans.name: Fatma

texts.fr:
Mme. Fatma S. sollicite son premier crédit pour investir dans son activité principale: le commerce de tissus et crèmes.  Elle a épousé le métier du commerce par le biais de sa soeur qui l'a élevée.  Elle vendait à Sandaga (le grand marché de Dakar) et puis à Gorée (un autre marché de Dakar).  Mme. S. explique qu'elle aime surtout l'indépendance financière dans le secteur.  
Elle est divorcée et mère de deux enfants, âgés de 9 et 12 ans.
texts.en:
Mrs. Fatma S. is requesting her first loan to invest in her business: sales of fabric and creams. She started out in her business following her sister's occupation because she was raised by her. She sells in Sandaga (the large market in Dakar) and in Goree (another market in Dakar). Mrs. S. indicates that she loves being financially independent.

She is divorced and she is the mother of two children, aged 9 and 12 years old.


Translated from French by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase textile fabrics and creams.

loans.name: Jumoke

texts.en:
Jumoke is 35 years old. She is a hardworking woman and a committed member of her group, and she has been borrowing from LAPO for years. She sells sarongs; she has been in business for ten years. Jumoke's focus is to expand her business and make sure customers' demands are met, thereby improving her own financial situation.

Jumoke is requesting a loan of 80,000 Nigerian naira to purchase sarongs to sell. She says thank you and promises to repay promptly.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs to sell

loans.name: Tièssiri Group

texts.fr:
Le groupe Tièssiri est composé de femmes mariées dans des ménages monogames. Elles ont en moyenne 41 ans, 6 enfants et habitent dans le quartier Pelengana Sud de Ségou (4ème Région administrative  de la république du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de mariage et d’appartenance à une même association traditionnelle des femmes du quartier. 
Ce groupe fait le commerce d’articles divers et la fabrication de savon traditionnels.
Dans le souci de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle de plus en plus nombreuse, elles ont décidé d’intégrer  le programme de crédit de Soro Yiriwaso avec qui elles sont à leur 3ème  prêt solidaire après avoir  remboursé les deux précédents. 
Ce  nouveau prêt sera utilisé pour acheter,  24 paires de chaussures, 2 barriques de 200 litres d’huile alimentaires, 2 barriques de résidus d’huile raffinée, 25kg de soude caustique, 30 sachets d’Omo et  50kg de gomme. 
Elles s’approvisionnent en chaussures à Cotonou, en huile, soude caustique, Omo et gomme (produit à base de manioc utilisé pour rendre les habits blanchis lisses et brillants) au grand  marché de Ségou, en résidus d’huile à l’Huilerie Ba Mariama de Pelengana. 
Le savon local est obtenu en faisant longtemps cuire le résidu d’huile puis elle ajoute de la soude caustique, une quantité suffisante de gomme et de l’Omo ce mélange est malaxé jusqu’à  devenir homogène. Elle laisse refroidir cette pâte puis elle la pétris  en boules en portant des gants, puis ces savons en boules  sont mis  sur le marché. 
La vente se fait généralement à domicile, en ambulant dans le quartier, en détail, au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femmes. 
Elles envisagent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 30.000FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement du prêt, à l’achat de fournitures scolaires et la prise en charge de certaines dépenses de la familles.
texts.en:
The Tièssiri group is made up of married women in monogamous households. On average, these women are 41 years of age and have six children. They live in the South Pelengana district of Segou (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). They came to know each other through neighborhood and family connections, and a traditional association of neighborhood women. This groups sells diverse products and makes traditional soaps. The women have decided to work with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution to better satisfy the needs of their growing clientele. This is their third group loan. The previous two were repaid.

This new loan will be used to buy 24 pairs of shoes, two 200-liter barrels of cooking oil, 2 barrels of refined oil residue, 25 kg of caustic soda, 30 packets of Omo, and 50 kg of resin. They get their supply of shoes at Cotonou, oil, caustic soda, Omo and starch (product derived from cassava that is used to make white garments smooth and shiny) at the Segou grand market, and oil residue from the Ba Mariama of Pelengan oil plant.

The native soap is made by cooking the oil residue for a long time, then adding caustic soda, a sufficient quantity of resin and the Omo. The mixture is blended until it is homogenous. This paste is cooled and shaped into balls while wearing gloves. These soap balls are then sold near home by walking through the neighborhood and in retail stores. The sales are done in cash and on credit to male and female customers. An average monthly revenue of 30 000 CFA francs is expected, which will be used to pay off the loan, buy school supplies and pay for certain family expenses.

Translated from French by Joanne Archambault, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase diverse products

loans.name: Mohira

texts.en:
K. Mohira is the 32-year-old loving mother of two children. Her husband is an electrician. For more than 7 years Mohira has sold fish in the central fish market of the city. When she started she made only a little money in turnover. With time her business expanded and today it is quite a stable business. Mohira requests a loan of $1500 USD. She wants to purchase a lot of fish at wholesale prices in order to have stock to sell in winter. Mohira has already been provided with three loans by IMON and has shown herself to be a reliable client. She would to thank everyone for their support.   


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase fish wholesale.

loans.name: Yèrèdèmè Group

texts.fr:
Yèrèdèmè est un regroupement de 4 femmes mariées dans des ménages monogames ayant en moyenne 41 ans, 5 enfants et  habitant dans  le quartier Pelengana Sud de la ville de Ségou (4ème Région administrative de la république du Mali). 
Elles se sont connues à travers des liens de voisinage, de mariage.
Ce groupe de femmes fait le commerce d’articles divers et décida d’intégrer le  programme crédit de Soro Yiriwaso, avec qui elles sont à leur 3ème  prêt solidaire après avoir remboursé les deux précédents, afin de satisfaire sa clientèle en nette croissance . 
Ce troisième prêt sera utilisé pour acheter, 2 pièces de 30 mètres de bazin, 10 tenues pantalon chemises, 10 tenues culottes chemises,10 tenues jupe tee shorts,  6 robes, 24 flacons de parfums, une douzaine de crèmes à lèvre, 2 paquets de boucles d’oreille et  2 douzaines de portes monnaies. 
Elles s’approvisionnent en bazin blanc au grand marché pour ensuite les teindre, les habits pour enfants et les portes monnaies sont également achetés au grand marché de Ségou, les parfums, les crèmes à lèvre, les boucles d’oreille sont achetés au  Burkina Faso. 
La vente de leurs marchandises se fait généralement au marché château de Ségou, à domicile et en ambulant  dans le quartier au comptant et à crédit à une clientèle composée d’homme et de femmes. 
Elles  espèrent réaliser un bénéfice moyen mensuel de 32.750FCFA qui sera utilisé pour le remboursement du prêt de Soro Yiriwaso, la contribution dans la prise en charges de certaines dépenses familiales et la participation aux évènements sociaux (mariages, baptêmes, circoncisions et funérailles). 
Leurs ambitions se résument à l’augmentation du montant de leurs prêts avenir.
texts.en:
Yèrèdèmè is made up of four married women who are in monogamous marriages. They average 41 years of age, five children and live in the Pelengana South neighbourhood of the city of Segou (Fourth admnistrative region of Mali). They know one another through being neighbours and by marriage. This group of women sells a variety of goods and decided to join the loan programme of Soro Yiriwaso in order to satisfy customer demand, which is growing markedly. This is their third group loan, having repaid their two previous loans in full.
