This third loan will be used to buy two 30-metre rolls of bazin cloth, 10 pant and shirt outfits, 10 short and shirt outfits, 10 skirt and t-shirt outfits, 6 dresses, 24 bottles of perfume, a dozen lipsticks, 2 packages of earrings and 2 dozen wallets. They buy the white bazin cloth from the main market and then dye it. The children's clothing and wallets are also purchased at the main market of Segou. The perfume, lipsticks and earrings are bought in Burkina Faso. They generally sell their goods at the Château market in Segou, from home or on foot in their neighbourhood. They sell for cash and on credit to both men and women. They hope to make 32,750 CFA monthly with which they will repay the loan from Soro Yiriwaso and contribute to some of their household expenses as well as for a number of social events (marriages, baptisms, circumcisions and funerals). Their goal is to be able to apply for greater loans in the future.

Translated from French by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a variety of goods

loans.name: Saliou Mbacke

texts.en:
Mr. Saliou Mbacke S. is a "commercant" (a trader or vendor) in the main market of Bambey, which is a rural town about 100 kilometers from Dakar. He has been in this business for 20 years, carrying on the tradition began by his father, and he sells unsweetened peanut paste and palm oil, which are ingredients used in many Senegalese dishes, such as Mafi and Soup Kandia. He also sells hand-made brooms.

Through this loan of 400,000 FCFA, he would like to replenish his stock. With the income from his business, he is helping his wife with her small breakfast canteen, also located in the market. The Senes have four children.

loans.use: To replenish his stock of brooms, peanut paste, and palm oil

loans.name: Abdukholik

texts.en:
M. Abdukholik is 26 years old, living with his wife and two children. He has been breeding cattle for more than 5 years and he is trying to improve the breed in order to increase his prices. He invests time and money in the feed and medicines that the animals require. He enjoys this work, above all getting milk from his cows, which his wife sells in local markets. Abdukholik keeps going thanks to the help and enthusiasm of his children, along with his wife who helps him to care for the animals. Now Abdukholik needs a loan of $1100 USD to purchase more cattle to expand his business. With your help this will be possible.   


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To purchase cattle.

loans.name: Joke

texts.en:
Joke is 40 years old, is married and has 4 children. She is a member of a LAPO group and has been borrowing from LAPO for years. Joke sells books and provisions; she has been in this business for the past ten years. She is focused on making sure she meets the demands of her customers, which she says will also lead to an increase in profits for her.

Joke is asking for a loan of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase books and provisions in bulk, as this will enable her to get a better discount and more profit on each sale. She promises to pay the loan back promptly and says thank you.

loans.use: To purchase more books and provisions to sell

loans.name: Mame Aly

texts.en:
Mr. Mame Aly L. sells cereals in the rural community of Bambey, about 100 km from Dakar.  UIMCEC recently opened a branch in the town to better serve the rural clientele, and Mr. L. is one of its first members.
Mr. L. is very active in the community.  He is the head of the local branch of the ASC (Association Sportive et Culturelle) which sponsors sports events for young people in the community.  He also supports young entrepreneurs with small loans, as they often find it difficult to be able to get financing or merchandise on credit.  
With his loan of 200,000, Mr. L. would like to purchase Niébé (a local cereal) in bulk which he will then sell in town.  He is married with four children, the youngest aged 16.

loans.use: To purchase stock of Niébe (local cereal).

loans.name: Norma

texts.en:
Rice farming is the main source of living of Norma, 55. She owns a rice field in South Cotabato that is 3 hectares wide. She requested a loan of 15,000 PHP from Community Economic Ventures, Inc. to fill the needs of her rice field. She needs to buy fertilizers and other farm supplies. 

Norma is the mother of 3 children. She is married to Benito. Together they work hard to sustain their farm and family.

loans.use: To buy fertilizers and farm supplies.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
Ruth sells foodstuffs like tomato paste, rice, oil, beans and drinks. She has been in business for the past ten years and with this trade she assists her husband with the children's upbringing. Ruth is a faithful LAPO client. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 Nigerian naira to enable her to purchase more foodstuffs and drinks in bulk, which will enable her to meet customers' demands while increasing her profits. She puts in long hours trying to keep her businesses sustainable. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers.

Ruth is 49 years old and has five children. She says thank you and promises to pay back her loan promptly.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and drinks to sell

loans.name: Miroslava

texts.en:
Miroslava is married with a baby son. She is an entrepreneur from Korolyovo where she owns a little store selling fabrics, tulle, curtains and drapes. Miroslava basically has no competitors which makes it easier for her to run her small venture. She has been in this market for 5 years. Currently, she has 60,000 Grivnyas worth of inventory. Her profit amounts to 4,000 Grivnyas. 

Miroslava is seeking a 6,500 Grivnya loan to increase the assortment of merchandise she offers for sale in her kiosk. The loan will enable her to significantly expand her business by attracting new clients. Miroslava is hoping to reinvest generated income into further expansion of her business. She believes that consistent growth will help her provide a stable source of income and continue to secure her family’s well-being.

loans.use: To increase the variety of items she sells.

loans.name: Faten

texts.en:
Faten S. from Bethlehem is a wife and the mother of three children. She is also one of FATEN’s most committed clients. She works in a tourist card business with the help of her family members. Faten buys cards, then prints statements on them and adds her own touch by decorating them with flowers, ribbons and olive-tree leaves. She then sells them to souvenir shops.

As the holidays are around the corner, Faten requested a loan from FATEN in order to buy a larger quantity of cards and extra raw materials to meet the demand of the tourism high season. Faten appears in the photo with some of her products.

For the last ten years, Mrs. S.’s husband has worked with olive-tree wood and also grows some flowers and vegetables in his house garden. He also works with his wife.

By coincidence, this borrower’s name is the same as the microfinance institute (MFI) name: FATEN. It means lovely lady in Arabic but for FATEN MFI it is the first letters of the Arabic abbreviation of “Palestine for Credit and Development”.

loans.use: To purchase more raw materials for producing tourist cards

loans.name: Azam

texts.en:
N. Azam is 41 years old. He is married and has two children His wife is a housekeeper. Azam is processing and selling dried apricots in the central local market. He is experienced in the business of making the dried apricots. As a rule he purchases dried apricot in the market and processes them himself. Because he buys dried apricot wholesale, his prices are lower than regular market prices. He offers a wide assortment of goods for clients of different means. All this allows Azam to make his business quite successful and it brings the stable income for the family. Today Azam requests $1500 USD for purchasing dried apricot further to process it and to sell. He would like to increase his income and give his children a good education. Azam expresses his gratitude for everyone supporting him. 


More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To increase his range of goods.

loans.name: Ivan

texts.en:
Ivan is married with a 13-year-old son. He lives in Ivano-Frankivsk and runs a retail sale business. Ivan owns two vending kiosks and sells footwear, handbags and purses in the central market of his home town. He offers his inventory at reasonable prices which attracts a lot of potential customers to his business. Ivan has been in this trade for nineteen years. Currently, his income amounts to 7,000 Grivnyas a month.

Ivan is seeking a loan of 12,000 Grivnyas to purchase one hundred pairs of footwear to increase the assorted merchandise he offers for sale in his kiosks. Ivan is very focused and always works hard to see his business flourish and grow. He is hoping to invest the generated profit in the purchase of a private house which has always been his dream.

loans.use: To purchase 100 pairs of shoes

loans.name: Janet

texts.en: Janet is 54 years old and is a widow with four children. She lives in Oyo state and has been in business for 12 years. She owns a restaurant where she sells drinks and pepper soup. She puts in long hours trying to keep her businesses sustainable. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers. Janet is requesting a loan of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more drinks to sell. She says thank you and promises to pay her loan back promptly.

loans.use: To purchase more drinks to sell

loans.name: Gloria's Group

texts.es:
El comité Mujeres Madres Unidas del barrio Caacupemi de la ciudad de Aregua, se forma a causa de que integrantes del comité Mujeres unidas del mismo barrio invitaron a sus vecinas a integrarse en el comité y viendo que la cantidad de integrantes sobrepasaba la cantidad máxima requerida, decidieron formar un nuevo comité. 
Actualmente el comité se encuentra en el quinto ciclo del programa Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras de la Fundación Paraguaya y esta conformado por 21 integrantes las cuales invierten en distintas actividades.

La señora Gloria A. de dedica a la venta de frutas y dulces e invirtió el dinero en la compra de insumos para el incremento de su negocio. 

La señora Rosa L. se dedica venta de bijouterie e invirtió el dinero en la compra de bijouterie para venta de sus productos.

La señora Cirila V. se dedica a la venta de hierbas medicinales e invirtió el dinero en la compra de insumos para su venta.

La señora Juana F. tiene una despensa e invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías al por mayor para el incremento de su negocio. 

La señora Daysi O.  tiene una despensa e invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías al por mayor para el incremento de su negocio. 

La señora Delia F. se dedica venta de mercadería para despensas e invirtió el dinero en la compra de insumos tales como azúcar, yerba, harina, leche, papel higiénico, pañales entre otros, al por mayor.

La señora María Lourdes O. se dedica a la venta de golosinas e invirtió el dinero en la compra de insumos para la 
venta de sus productos.

La señora María Nilce M.  se dedica al reciclaje e invirtió el dinero en la compra de insumos para la venta y compra de los mismos.

La señora Eugenia G. se dedica a la venta de golosinas e invirtió el dinero en la compra de mas mercaderías para su venta posterior. 

La señora Amada A. se dedica a la venta de golosinas e invirtió el dinero en la compra de mas mercaderías para su venta posterior. 

La señora María Elizabeth M. se dedica al reciclaje e invirtió el dinero en la compra y venta de plásticos.

La señora Gabina U. se dedica a la venta de golosinas e invirtió el dinero en la compra de mas mercaderías para su venta posterior. 

La señora Emiliana N. se dedica a la venta de ropas e invirtió el dinero en la compra de prendas varias para su venta posterior.

La señora Noemi M. se dedica a la venta de ropas e invirtió el dinero en la compra de prendas varias para su venta posterior.

La señora María Casilda O. dedica a la venta de comestible e invirtio el dinero en la compra de insumos para la elaboración y venta de los mismos.

La señora Cintia L. se dedica venta de mercadería para despensas e invirtió el dinero en la compra de insumos tales como azúcar, yerba, harina, leche, papel higiénico, pañales entre otros, al por mayor.

La señora Susana N. tiene una despensa e invirtió el dinero en la compra de mercaderías para el incremento de su negocio.

La señora Mabel U. se dedica a la venta de helados e invirtió el dinero en la compra al por mayor en variedad de sabores para el incremento de su negocio.

La señora Miryans L.  se dedica a la venta de frutas e invirtió el dinero en la compra al por mayor de frutas varias para el incremento de su negocio.

La señora Sonia V. se dedica a la venta de frutas e invirtió el dinero en la compra al por mayor de frutas varias para el incremento de su negocio.

La señora Sara V. se dedica a la venta de sabanas e invirtió el dinero en la compra de telas e hilos para la confección y venta de las mismas.
texts.en:
The Mujeres Madres Unidas (Mothers United) group from the Caacupemi neighborhood in the city of Arequa formed because the women of the Mujeres United (Women United) group from the same neighborhood invited their neighbors to join them but seeing as the quanity of participants was more than the allowed limit, they decided to form a new group. Currently the group is in its fifth loan cycle of the Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras de la Fundación Paraguaya and is made up of 21 members who use the loan proceeds for different activities. Mrs. Gloria A. sells fruit and candy and used the loan to purchase goods to expand her business. Mrs. Rosa L. sells jewelry and she used to loan to purchase more inventory. Mrs. Cirila V. sells medicinal herbs and she used the loan to purchase more goods to sell. Mrs. Juana F. has a grocery store and she used the loan to buy wholesale merchandise to expand her business. Mrs. Daysi O. has a grocery store and she used the loan to buy wholesale merchandise to expand her business. Mrs. Delia F. sells merchandise to grocery stores and she used the loan to buy products on a wholesale basis such as sugar, herbs, flour, milk, toilet paper and diapers among other things. Mrs. María Lourdes O. sells candies and she used the loan to buy more goods to sell. Mrs. María Nilce M. works in recycling and she used the loan for buying and selling recycled goods. Mrs. Eugenia G. sells candies and she used the loan to buy more merchandise to sell. Mrs. Amada A. sells candies and she used the loan to buy more merchandise to sell. Mrs. María Elizabeth M. works in recycling and she used the loan for buying and selling plastic. Mrs. Gabina U. sells candies and she used the loan to buy more merchandise to sell. Mrs. Emiliana N. sells clothing and she used the loan to buy more garments to sell. Mrs. Noemi M. sells clothing and she used the loan to buy more garments to sell Mrs. María Casilda O. sells food and she used the loan to buy ingredients for food preparation. Mrs. Cintia L. sells merchandise to grocery stores and she used the loan to buy products on a wholesale basis such as sugar, spices, flour, milk, toilet paper and diapers among other things. Mrs. Susana N. has a grocery store and she used the loan to buy merchandise to expand her business. Mrs. Mabel U. sells ice cream and she used the loan to buy a variety of flavors on a wholesale basis. Mrs. Miryans L. sells fruit and she used the loan to buy fruit wholesale. Mrs. Sonia V. sells fruit and she used the loan to buy fruit wholesale. Mrs. Sara V. sells sheets and she used the loan to buy cloth and thread to make the sheets.

Translated from Spanish by Kristina Howe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of fruits and vegetables, candies, jewelry, medicinal herbs, meat, bakery goods, milk, sugar, flour, spices, plastics and other items

loans.name: Munavvar

texts.en:
R. Munavvar is 43-year old loving mother of three children. For more than 17 years, Munavvar has sold fish in the central fish market of the city. When she started she had only $100 United States dollars (USD) in turnover. With time, her business expanded and today it is a quite stable business. Munavvar has requested a loan in the amount of $1,500 USD. She wants to purchase a quantity of fish at wholesale prices in order to have stock to sell during the New Year's celebration when fishing is prohibited. Munavvar has shown herself to be a reliable client and has been already provided with the loan by IMON. She would like to thank everyone for their support.
More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to epic mountain passes, communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy a quantity of fish at wholesale prices for resale during New Year's celebration.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of icecream

loans.name: Ayoni

texts.en: Ayoni is 57 years old and is married with 4 children. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. She is a Lift Above Poverty Organization (LAPO) client. LAPO is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa. She sells palm kernels at retail prices to her customers to make a living. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers. She is requesting a loan of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase more palm kernels to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more palm kernels to sell

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: Rosemary is thirty-five years old. She is married and has given birth to two children who are both in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing-dominated community in the central region of Ghana. Rosemary is a fashion designer. She designs and sews dresses for sale and also for clients who place orders. She works in a shop by the road in her community. She has two apprentices under her training. Rosemary has been in business for seven years and desires to give her business a face-lift. She wants the loan to procure many kinds of printed fabric and other accessories in bulk to achieve this dream.

loans.use: To buy printed fabric and other accessories in bulk

loans.name: Alberta

texts.en: Alberta is thirty-nine years old. She is married and has given birth to two children who are both in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. Alberta works hard to support her husband in providing for the family. She is a fish monger. She buys fresh fish, smokes them, and supplies the smoked fish to food vendors. She buys the fresh fish directly from the fishermen in her community. Alberta has been in business for ten years and yearns to increase her stock. It is her desire to give all her children a good education.

loans.use: To buy fresh fish

loans.name: Vida

texts.en: Vida is thirty-eight years old. She is married and has given birth to four children who are all in school. She lives with her family in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. Vida works hard to support her husband in providing for the family. She trades in children’s clothing such as dresses and panties. She sells door-to-door and also treks to nearby communities to sell. She buys her goods from Accra. Vida has been in business for over ten years and wants a loan to increase her stock. It is her desire to give all her children a good education.

loans.use: To buy infants’ layettes (complete outfits of clothing and equipment for infants)

loans.name: Aba

texts.en: Aba is 50 years old, divorced and has two children, both of whom are in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in central Ghana. Aba works hard as a food vendor to provide for her family. She prepares and sells kenkey, a popular local dish, with fried fish by the roadside. She also sells various other items. Aba buys her maize from nearby farms, and has been in business for more than 25 years. She has applied for a loan to buy maize and other ingredients in bulk to use for her business.

loans.use: To buy ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Abduvali

texts.en:
U. Abduvali, whose wife is pictured here, is 28 years old. He learned his profession as a farmer from his father when he was young. After he married, he continued working in the same business, watching the business grow as a result of his sacrifice. At the same time, his family has progressed more and more. In addition to farming, Abduvali, with the help of his wife, buys and sells cattle to generate more profit. With his previous loans, Abduvali purchased two cattle. He has sold them already and has purchased two young calves that he is rearing to sell. Today he wants to expand his business and buy more cattle and fertilizer for his land. He is requesting a loan of $1,100 United States dollars (USD). From the profit of his business, Abduvali wants to educate his children. With your help this will be possible.
More about Tajikistan and IMON International Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions. But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: To buy cattle to expand his business.

loans.name: Mohammad

texts.en:
Mohammad is a Palestinian man living in the city of Nablus. He owns and manages a grocery shop which he has owned for  six years. It is the only source of income for his family which consists of six members. The business is going very well and there is good demand for its products,

Mohammad requested 2,000 USD from FATEN to pay in cash for some products he previously bought on credit as paying in cash will give him a better price and better product quality. The cost of the loan is much less than the cost of buying stuff from the merchants on credit.

Mohammad appears in the photo at his store.

loans.use: To buy products for his grocery shop using cash instead of credit

loans.name: Jemila

texts.en: Jemila is 37 years old, married and has three children, all of whom are currently in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a tourist community on Ghana's central coast. Many people in this area fish for a living, but Jemila runs a roadside store. She gets her goods from the capital, Accra. Jemila has been in business for 11 years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk.

loans.use: To buy items in bulk to sell in her store

loans.name: Idowu

texts.en:
Idowu is 54 years old, married and has five children. He lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. He is a LAPO client who makes a living selling plastic and building materials. Idowu loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He is requesting a loan for NGN 60,000 to buy more plastic items to sell. He extends his sincerest thanks to all Kiva lenders for their support.   

LAPO (Lift Above Poverty Organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To buy more plastics to sell

loans.name: Margaret

texts.en: Margaret is 35 years old, married and has five children, all of whom are all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in central Ghana. Margaret and her husband work hard to support their family. She is a food vendor who prepares and sells kenkey, a popular local dish, with fried fish. She sells by the roadside and buys bags of maize from nearby farming communities. Margaret has been in business for over 15 years and wants a loan to buy ingredients in bulk so that she can expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize and other ingredients

loans.name: Sophia

texts.en: Sophia is 36 years of age, married and has two children, both of whom are currently in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a tourist community that is located on the central coast of Ghana. The main occupation of the people in this area is fishing. Sophia makes a living as a trader, running a roadside store. She procures her goods from the capital, Accra. She has been in business for eight years and has applied for a loan to buy goods in bulk to sell to her customers.

loans.use: To buy goods in bulk to sell to her customers

loans.name: Balogun

texts.en:
Balogun is 60 years old and is married with nine children. He lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria.

Balogun sells palm kernel at retail prices to his customers to make a living. He loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that he has with his customers. He is requesting a loan of NGN 100,000 to purchase more palm kernel to sell. He says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

Balogun is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above poverty organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

loans.use: To purchase more palm kernel to sell

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa is forty-seven years of age. She is married and has given birth to two children, both of whom are in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a tourist-attraction community in the central region of Ghana. The community is one of the coastal towns in Ghana and as a result, the major occupation of the people is farming.

Adwoa is a trader. She trades in vegetable cooking oil and other food items. She procures her goods from nearby towns and sells in a store in her community. She has been in business for seven years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to increase her stock.

loans.use: To buy cooking oil in bulk

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en:
Adwoa is forty-three years old. She is married and she has five children who are all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana.

Adwoa works hard to support her husband and to provide for the family. She is a fish monger. She buys fresh fish, smokes it and then supplies the fish to food vendors. She buys fresh fish directly from the fishermen in her community.

Adwoa has been in business for twenty-five years and yearns to increase her stock. It is her desire to give all her children a good education. For this reason she has requested a loan.

loans.use: To buy fresh fish

loans.name: Shade

texts.en:
Shade sells frozen foods and sarongs. She has been in business for twenty years and with this business she supports her husband in providing for the family. She is a very hardworking and focused woman.

With this loan of N100,000, Shade plans to expand her frozen food and sarongs business, which is now booming. With this kind of business she hopes to increase her earnings in the long run and be able to better provide for her children's education.

Shade is 36 years old, is married and has three children. She says thank you to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more sarongs and frozen food to sell

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en:
Gloria is thirty-eight years old. She is married and has given birth to four children who are all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana.

Gloria works hard to support her husband and to provide for the family. She is a food vendor. She prepares and sells kenkey with fried fish. Gloria sells by the road side. She buys bags of maize from nearby farming communities.

Gloria has been in business for five years and wants a loan to procure bags of maize and other ingredients in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize

loans.name: Esi

texts.en:
Esi is twenty-seven years old. She is divorced and has given birth to two children who are both in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana.

Esi works hard to be able to provide for her family. She is a food vendor. She buys bags of maize from nearby farming communities and prepares and sells kenkey (fermented corn and cassava dough, wrapped in corn or banana leaves) with fried fish which she sells on a table by the roadside.

Esi has been in business for over ten years and wants a loan to procure bags of maize and other ingredients in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize and other ingredients in bulk

loans.name: Magret

texts.en:
Magret is 46 years old. She is married with 4 children. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. She is a LAPO client. LAPO (Lift above poverty organization) is committed to improving lives in Nigeria and elsewhere in Africa.

Margret sells crates of drinks at retail prices to her customers to make a living. She loves this business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers.

She is requesting a loan amount of NGN70,000 to purchase more crates of drinks to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more crates of drinks to sell

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en: Lydia is forty-seven years of age. She is married and has given birth to three children, all of whom are in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a community popular with tourists in the central region of Ghana. The community is one of the coastal towns in Ghana. As a result, the major occupation of the people is fishing. Lydia is a trader. She trades in provisions. She sells the provisions on a table top in the market square in her community. She procures her goods from Accra. Lydia has been in business for eight years and wants a loan to buy goods in bulk to increase her stock.

loans.use: To buy provisions

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 53 years old, married and has four children. She is a committed LAPO client. She sells kerosene. She has been in business for close to six years and is requesting a loan of 100,000 Nigerian naira to purchase kerosene in bulk at a reduced price, thereby increasing her profit and, she hopes, meeting customers' demand. With this business, she hopes to increase her earnings in the long run and be able to better provide for her children's education. She says thank you to all lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more kerosene to sell

loans.name: Celestina

texts.en: Celestina is twenty-nine years old. She is single and has no child. She lives alone in a rented apartment in a fishing-dominated community in the central region of Ghana. She is a trader. Celestina trades in ready-made women's clothing. She sells door-to-door and treks to nearby communities to sell on their market days. Celestina has been in business for three years and desires to give her business a face-lift. She therefore wants a loan, which she will use to procure more goods.

loans.use: To buy ready-made clothing

loans.name: Adwoa

texts.en: Adwoa is thirty-five years old. She is divorced and has given birth to two children, both of whom are in school. She lives with her children in a rented apartment in a fishing community in the central region of Ghana. Adwoa works hard to be able to provide for her family. She is a trader; she trades in maize. She supplies the maize to food vendors in her community. She also treks to nearby towns to supply vendors there. Adwoa buys bags of maize from nearby farming communities. She has been in business for five years and wants a loan to procure bags of maize in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy bags of maize

loans.name: Shola

texts.en: Shola is 30 years old. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo state, Nigeria. She has been in this business for a long time. Shola owns a medicine store where she sells medicines to make a living. she hopes for a loan amount of 50,000 NGN to purchase medicines to sell. She is happy with her business because of the one-on-one interaction that she has with her customers.She hopes to expand her business in the future.She is indeed grateful to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Buy merchandise and supplies for their businesses

loans.name: Kudirat

texts.en:
Kudirat is 33 years old. She is married with two children who are 8 and 4 years old and they are both doing well in school. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. Her husband sells tires and they both contribute to supporting the family.

Kudirat puts in long hours trying to keep her businesses sustainable. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers. She is requesting the loan of N50,000 to purchase more medicines to sell. She says thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more medicines to sell

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Buy merchandise for members' store, buy ingredients to make food, and buy tools for work

loans.name: Ramon

texts.es:
El señor Ramón R. tiene 29 años de edad, está casado con Norma Aguilera, viven en casa propia desde hace 2 años en la cuidad de Ñemby, no tienen hijos vivos, pero hace 2 años aproximadamente, tuvieron un hijo que nació con algunos problemas de salud y que no pudo sobrellevar y falleció a los pocos días, cuenta que esta experiencia los dejo bastante golpeados porque era su primer hijo y estaban muy ilusionados.
En ese entonces ambos tenían sus respectivas microempresas, ella se  tenía un comedor en el Mercado 4 , y él tenía un puesto de venta de calzados también dentro del mercado.
Hoy su esposa está trabajando en una empresa , donde es encargada de la cocina, tiene un ingreso fijo, mientras que Ramón ahora tiene su puesto de ventas de bolsones y carteras para damas, sus ventas son al mayor y menor, según él con este nuevo rubro obtiene más ganancias,ya que él mismo junto con sus hermanos se dedican a la fabricación de sus propios productos.
texts.en:
Ramón R., 29, is married to Norma Aguilera. They have lived in their own house in the city of Ñemby for two years. They do not have any living children. Approximately two years ago they had a child who was born with some health problems. He could not survive, and he died a few days after being born. Dealing with this experience left them quite battered because it was their first child, and they had high hopes. At that time they both had their own respective small businesses. She had a restaurant in the Mercado 4. He had a stall selling footwear in the same market. Now his wife is working in a business where she is in charge of the kitchen. She has a regular income. Ramón now has a stall where he sells purses and wallets for women. He sells wholesale and retail. According to him, he gets greater income from this new field. Together with his siblings he makes his own products himself.

Translated from Spanish by Ginny Kalish, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy raw material like faux leather, leather, glue, tacks, and zippers

loans.name: Francisco

texts.es:
El señor Francisco A. tiene 57 años, es soltero y tiene 3 hijos, dos mujeres de 30 y 23 años que viven con la madre en Japón y un varón de 26 años que vive  y trabaja con él.
El mismo se dedica a la compra de carbón vegetal en forma mayorista, al fraccionamiento, venta y  reparto  del mismo en los negocios de la ciudad de Villa Elisa. 
Para el reparto utiliza  un camión Mercedes Benz 608 año 1974 de su propiedad.
El mismo desea invertir el préstamo en la compra de carbón por toneladas para abaratar de esa manera el costo de su mercadería y obtener mayor margen de ganancias sobres sus ventas.
texts.en:
Francisco A. is 57 years old, single, and has three children: two daughters, 23 and 30, who live with their mother in Japan and a son, 26 years old, who lives with Francisco. Francisco works buying charcoal at wholesale and breaking it into smaller pieces for sale and distribution to the businesses of Villa Elisa city. For distribution he uses his own 1974 Mercedes Benz model 608 truck. He wants to invest the loan in the purchase of charcoal by the ton in order to buy at a lower price and earn a better income on his sales.

Translated from Spanish by Daniel Burke, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy charcoal at wholesale to break up and resell

loans.name: Maria Lorena

texts.es:
La señorita  María Lorena, es una joven comerciante de 20 años de edad, la misma es soltera, y vive con sus padres aún, ademas de su negocio ella es estudiante de la facultad.
Manifiesta que toda su familia prácticamente son comerciantes, y que tenía una tía que tenía una despensa  con todo los equipos de trabajos , pero que luego decidió cerrar la despensa para dedicarse a la costura, y entonces ella vio la oportunidad de poner un negocio propio y adquirió los equipamientos de dicha despensa y desde entonces se dedica a la despensa.
Además dice que con el negocio le ayuda a generar ingresos y así también  poder seguir sus estudios que lo hace por la noche, para que pueda atender a sus clientes en el día.
texts.en:
Miss María Lorena is a young saleswoman of 20 years of age and is single. She lives with her parents and is also a student. She tells us that her whole family is in sales and that she had an aunt that had a grocery store but who decided to close the store to do tailoring instead. So María saw she had a chance to start her own business and bought all of the goods and equipment from her aunt's store and since then has been working in the business. She also tells us that the business helps her generate income and that allows her to continue her studies at night, attending to her customers during the day.

Translated from Spanish by Kristina Howe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of inventory

loans.name: Betty Antonila

texts.es:
Betty C. de 51 años de edad, tiene una casa de ladrillos ubicada en la zona Fortín de Guayaquil, Betty comenzó su negocio cuando vio que en su sector necesitaban una tienda de víveres y le gustaba mucho la idea de implementarla.

Ahora Betty trabaja en su tienda desde las 08h00 hasta las 20h30 todos los días incluyendo los domingos en su tienda tienen aceites, arroz, azúcar, colas, etc. Una de las mayores complicaciones son los ladrones por lo que Betty puso por mayor seguridad  rejas en su tienda. Su esposo le ayuda con los gastos familiares vendiendo caldo de salchicha, ellos tienen 2 hijos uno de 18 años y otro de 24 años ya todos en Universidad.

Con el préstamo quiere comprar más aceites, arroz, azúcar, y más víveres para su negocio. En el futuro quiere incrementar su negocio poniendo otro en otro sector, y así darle un buen futuro a su familia.
texts.en:
Betty C., 51 years old, has a brick house located in the Fortín neighborhood of Guayaquil. Betty began her business when she saw the need for a grocery store in her area, and she really enjoyed the thought of opening one. Now, Betty works in her store from 8:00 a.m. until 10:30 p.m. every day including Sundays. Her shop carries oil, rice, sugar, colas, etc. One of the major setbacks are burglars, so Betty has put bars on her store for better security. Her husband helps her with household expenses by selling sausage soup. They have 2 children, one 18-year-old and another 24-year-old, both in college. With this loan, she wants to buy more oil, rice, sugar, and more food products for her shop. In the future, she wants to expand her business, putting another one in another neighborhood, and that way give her family a better future.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Merchlewitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, oil, etc.

loans.name: Idowu

texts.en:
Idowu is 31 years old and is excited to take a Kiva loan with LAPO. He is single and lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria.

Idowu has a centre where his customers watch football (soccer) matches. One of his greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction he is able to have with his customers.

Idowu is requesting a loan of N50,000. With the loan, he plans to expand his football match business by adding another DSTV (Digital Satellite Television). With this kind of business he hopes to increase his earnings in the long run. He say thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase another DSTV to show football matches

loans.name: Igembe Group

texts.en:
Jambo (hello) from Tanzania! Judith M. is 28 years old and married. She and her husband have two daughters aged eight years and six months old. Judith owns a barber shop in the Tegeta community of Dar es Salaam and a beauty salon in Temeke, Dar es Salaam. She opened both of these businesses in 2005 after working for many years as a server at Steers, a local fast food restaurant. She says it was one of her proudest moments to finally be able to open her own business after saving for so long.

Judith received her first loan from Tujijenge in 2008. Since then she has taken four loans and has been able to hire two employees at the barber shop and two more at the salon. She splits her time between the two locations, bringing her six-month-old daughter to work with her and caring for her while carrying out her work duties.

While she was pregnant, Judith was worried about taking loans from Tujijenge because she was not able to work as much. Therefore, she did not receive a loan for the past two loan cycles. Now that she has given birth and is back to a regular work schedule, she is happy and excited to take another loan.

Judith hopes to use this loan to invest in more supplies for her barber shop and salon. She will purchase items such as hair tongs, scissors, combs, brushes, hair weave (hair extensions) and other hair products. She says she hopes to use any extra profits to pay her children's school fees and medical bills. Right now, Judith makes a profit of about 615 US Dollars per month. Her businesses are especially busy on Saturdays and Sundays, or when her customers need their hair done for weddings.

Judith will share this loan with the members of her group, Igembe. In the photo, Judith is sitting third from the left.

loans.use: To buy equipment and supplies for her barber shop and salon

loans.name: Lucia's Group

texts.es:
El comité se formo en la ciudad de San Lorenzo por medio de otro grupo que trabaja en la misma zona, el comité cuenta actualmente con 18 integrantes todas vecinas entre si. Domiciliadas en el barrio 15 de enero de la ciudad de San Lorenzo.-
todas las integrantes del comité trabajan en forma independiente y el crédito fue invertido de acuerdo a la actividad a que se dedican.
Unas de la señoras quien es Doña Maria G., ella  trabaja como vendedora ambulante de varios productos como ropa cosméticos, artículos personales entre otros, este trabajo lo realiza para mantener a sus dos hijos ya que es madre soltera y viven con su madre y debe ayudar con los gastos de la casa.  
Estas son las actividades a que se dedican cada una:

texts.en:
This group was formed in the city of San Lorenzo with the help of another group that worked in the same area. The group currently has 18 members, all neighbors. They live in the 15 de enero neighborhood of San Lorenzo. All of the members of the group work independently and the loan was invested in each of their separate activities. One of the women is Doña Maria G.. She works as a street vendor, selling a variety of products such as clothing and cosmetics. She works to be able to support her two kids since she is a single mother and has to cover household expenses. This is what each of the women do: 1 Lucía T. Sales 2 Auda F. Seamstress 3 Agustina D. Sales4 Marta G. Sales of Lingerie 5 Herminia Arzamendia Sales of Silverware and Clothing 6 Sonia C. Lottery Tickets 7 Nelida O. Seamstress 8 Veronica C. Sales 9 Elena R. Sales 10 Clara T. Fruit 11 Maria C. Sales 12 Gregoria Galvan Seamstress 13 Licia A. Seamstress 14 Maria A. Appliances 15 Estanisla B. Sales 16 Fermina V. Sales 17 Cristina B. Appliances 18 Maria G. Sales

Translated from Spanish by Kristina Howe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The loan was used to support the separate activities of each member of the group

loans.name: Lotus Group

texts.en:
Jambo (hello) from Tanzania! Bahati L. is a member of the Lotus loan group. She is 23 years old, unmarried, and has no children.

Bahati has owned and operated her own video library in the Mbezi area of Dar es Salaam for two years with no one assisting her. The video shop, where she rents and sells music and movies, is open from 8 a.m. till 6 p.m. daily. She has a mix of Tanzanian, Indian, and American films. You can rent a movie for two days for 1,000 Tanzanian shillings, or about .75 cents US. To buy a movie costs 3,500 shillings, or about $2.60.

This will be Bahati's second loan from Tujijenge. She will use it to increase her stock of CDs and DVDs. In the photo, Bahati is wearing a yellow shirt and resting her chin on her hand. She is sitting with all the members of her loan group.

loans.use: To buy more CDs and DVDs to rent and sell

loans.name: Prosperidad Group

texts.es:
El grupo Prosperidad está integrado por Marlyn V. de 40 años de edad quien vende cosméticos  y ropa de manera ambulantes. Ella invertirá el crédito en comprar lápiz labial, rubor, marbellí, delineador, polvo compacto, base y ropa entre otros productos para luego comercializarlo de manera ambulante. 

Sus compañeras son Yolanda R. N. que tiene una pulpería y Xiomara del Socorro que vende tortillas y frijoles. Estas tres mujeres aseguran que aunque tienen poco de tar con adim este le ayudado mucho a aumentar su negocio.
texts.en:
The Prosperidad (Prosperity) group is made up of Marlyn V. who is 40 years old and sells cosmetics and clothing as a street vendor. She will use the loan to buy lipstick, blush, eyeliner, compacts, foundation and clothing among other things to later sell on the street. Her companions are Yolanda R. N. who has a grocery store and Xiomara del Socorro who sells tortillas and beans. The three women tell us that although they have only been with ADIM for a short while, the loans have helped them grow their businesses.

Translated from Spanish by Kristina Howe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase cosmetics and clothing

loans.name: Melanie

texts.en:
Melanie G. is a 29-year old married woman with two children. Her oldest child is only six years old. Melanie has been engaged in farming since 2004. 

Melanie tells us that she is now preparing her farm for the next planting. She will need seeds, fertilizer, and other farming inputs. She is requesting a CEVI loan in the amount of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). With this loan, Melanie will be able to purchase the supplies she needs for her farm.

loans.use: To purchase farm supplies.

loans.name: Marites

texts.en:
Marites A. is 28 years old and married with three children. Her oldest child is 16 years old. Rice farming is Marites’s livelihood. Aside from farming, she also raises pigs to add income to her family. 

Marites aims to send all her children to school so that they may have a proper education. She works hard but still makes sure she has time for her family, especially her children.

Marites has been a member of CEVI since 2007. She tells us that her loans have really helped her business and her family. She is now applying for a loan in the amount of 15,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). She will use this loan to finance her farm.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies.

loans.name: Risika

texts.en:
Risika is 45 years old, married, and has four children; she lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria.

Risika sells foodstuffs like rice, beans, ground nuts (peanuts), eggs, drinks, etc. She is a focused, hard worker and puts in long hours trying to keep her businesses sustainable.

Risika is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase more foodstuffs to sell. She says thank you and promise to pay back promptly.

loans.use: To purchase more foodstuffs and drinks to sell

loans.name: Anna Mae

texts.en:
Ana Mae, 24 years old, has been married to her husband Rolan since 2005. They have a 4-year old child. 

Ana does farming for a living. She also runs a sari-sari (general) store, which provides daily income for her family. She dreams that someday she will be successful in her business. Ana and her husband cultivate their land for rice crops. Ana tell us that they are now preparing for planting. 

In December 2007, Ana Mae joined CEVI, an MFI in the Philippines. Her previous loans helped sustain their farm and her small store. In times of crisis, Ana Mae finds comfort through Biblical Reflections during Cluster Meetings. Ana is now requesting a loan in the amount of 12,000 Philippine pesos (PHP). She will use this loan to finance her farm.

loans.use: To buy farm supplies.

loans.name: Racilyn

texts.en:
Racilyn is a 28-year-old married woman who farms with her husband to earn a living. She has been married to Armando for three years. She and Armando do not yet have a child, but they pray to God to bless them with one. In addition to her farming activities, she also raises pigs to add to their income.

Racilyn is a member of CEVI, and she is now requesting a loan in the amount of 12,000 PHP ($275). This loan will be used to finance their farm and to care for her pigs. Specifically, she would like to buy seeds, fertilizer, and pig feed with this loan.

loans.use: To improve her businesses by purchashing seeds, fertilizer, and pig feed

loans.name: Lovelyn

texts.en:
Lovelyn is a 33-year-old married woman with two children. Her oldest child is just 13 years old, and her kids attend school. She would like for her children to finish their schooling (until college) and to find decent jobs.

To earn a living, Lovelyn is engaged in rice-farming and hog-raising. She explains that she is now preparing her land for planting. However, she needs additional capital for the farm and to care for her pigs. She joined CEVI and is now applying for a loan in the amount of 12,000 PHP ($275). This loan will be used to finance Lovelyn’s farming activities and to provide feed for the pigs.

loans.use: To improve her business by purchasing farming necessities and pig feed

loans.name: Lilibeth

texts.en:
Lilibeth is a 39-year-old married woman with three children. Her oldest child is now 10 years old and attends school. Like any mother, she wants all of her children to receive a proper education.

To earn a living, Lilibeth is engaged in rice farming. Indeed, she owns a one-hectare rice field. She explains that she and some laborers are currently preparing her land for planting. In addition, she runs a small store, which helps her provide for her family’s daily living needs. Lilibeth is now seeking a loan in the amount of 15,000 PHP ($325) to better finance her farming operations. More specifically, she would like to buy seeds, fertilizer, and other farming necessities, and to pay the laborers she hired to work at her farm.

loans.use: To expand and improve her business by purchasing farming necessities (e.g., seeds and fertilizer) and by paying her laborers

loans.name: Naranjaisy Group

texts.es:
El comité “Naranjaisy Poty” se formó con la unión varias vecinas de la Compañia Naranjaisy ciudad de  Villeta.  Todas las integrantes del comité desarrollan actividades independientes, como son las ventas. 
Todas las integrantes del comité son madres que se dedican a varias actividades con el fin de fortalecer la economía de la casa y desarrollar sus emprendimientos de manera sustentable y con vistas a un crecimiento constante, con la ayuda de una asistencia financiera permanente.

Hablaremos especialmente de la Señora Fredesvinda Noelaia S. de Fragueda quien tiene 66 años de edad, esta casada hace más de 40 años, vive en la casa de la calle 12 de Octubre de la Compañia Naranjaisy de la Ciudad de Villeta, es Artesana especializada en la confección de Prendas  de Ao Poi. 
Ella tiene 4 hijas ya mayores, casadas con hijos, tiene 6 nietos, es una lider en su comunidad, aprendió el oficio en cursos que traía el Gobierno a la ciudad en años anteriores. Hoy en dia la señora Noelia como la conocen enseña dos veces por semana tan hermoso arte tradicional paraguayo a otras mujeres de todas las edades en el local del Departamento de Cultura de la Municipalidad de Villeta.
La Prof. Noelia es una mujer multifacética quien apoya a su comunidad.

texts.en:
The Naranjaisy Poty group is made up of a number of neighbours from the Naranjaisy neighbourhood in the city of Villeta. All the members have their own independent small business, such as sales. All the members of this group are mothers who have a variety of economic activities with the goal of increasing their household income and of developing their enterprises in a sustainable manner and in view of steady growth, with the help of ongoing financial assistance. We will focus on Mrs. Fredesvinda Noelia S. de Fragueda who is 66 years old and has been married for over 40 years. She lives in a house on 12 de Octubre road in Naranjaisy neighbourhood in the city of Villeta. She is an artisan specializing in making clothing from Ao Poi, a type of a fine cotton cloth. She has four adult daughters who are married and have children of their own. She has six grandchildren and is a community leader. She learned her trade thanks to municipal government courses which she took in previous years. Today, Noelia, as she is known, teaches twice weekly courses in her beautiful traditional Paraguayan art to other women of all ages in the offices of the Department of Culture of the Municipality of Villeta. Noelia is a multi-faceted woman who supports her community. 1 Jorgelina Centurión - Ao Poí artisan 2 Rosa B. de D. - Cosmetics sales 3 Elisea G. de González - Food sales 4 Noelia Fredesvinda S. - Ao Poí artisan 5 Juana R. - Confectionery 6 Juliana A. - Artisan 7 Blasida F. - Seamstress 8 Alba Isabel Fragueda - Cosmetics Sales 9 Blanca Lydia F. - Clothing Sales 10 Pabla O. - Fruit Sales 11 María Esther F. - Convenience Store 12 Yenny G. - Artisan 13 Lilian Ester A. - Hen Breeding 14 Norma Lilian Nuñez - Cosmetics Sales 15 Claudelina Duate - Cosmetics Sales 16 Wilma Emilce D. - Cosmetics Sales 17 Lidia G. R. - Ao Poi Artisan 18 Rita Aidee R. - Poultry Breeding

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Each of the group members sells a variety of goods such as clothing, rice, sugar, dairy products, poultry breeding, cosmetics, Ao Poi crafts and so on and their loans were used to purchase those products.

loans.name: Lidia

texts.es: Lidia tiene 34 años, vive con su pareja y sus dos hijos en su casa propia.Se dedica a la venta de salchipapas (platillo compuesto de salchichas y papas fritas),  además tiene una tienda de abarrotes en su vivienda que esta ubicada un poco alejada de la ciudad, es por esta razón que logra buenas ventas ya que es el único negocio que ofrece este delicioso  platillo en su zona; los clientes la frecuentan muy seguido, ya que el mercado donde venden algo similar se encuentra a media hora. Lidia se siente contenta con su trabajo porque  le permite salir adelante al lado de su familia, y  atiende con mucho empeño a todos los clientes, además  es  una persona muy querida en su vecindario, y trabaja siempre pensando  en el futuro, quiere brindarles mayor estabilidad a sus hijos.Es su primer préstamo con  MFP y promete ser muy responsable con todas las cuotas.Con el dinero del crédito  quiere comprar mayor cantidad de papas( tubérculos peruanos) para aumentar la producción de platos y además quiere abastecer de panetones (bizcochos navideños)  su tienda, para venderlos por navidad y obtener buenas ganancias.
texts.en:
Lidia is 34 years old, lives with her partner in her own house, and has two children. She sells a type of food called "salchipapas," a dish made from sausage (salchichas) and french fries (papas fritas). She also has a grocery store that she runs out of her home, which is located outside the city. She makes good sales as she is the only business in her area that offers the delicious dish. Her customers come to her very often since the other market that sells something similar is a half an hour away. Lidia feels very happy with her job because it lets her her and her family succeed, and she is very dedicated to attending to her customers. She is also a very well-liked person in her neighborhood, and she always works with a mind toward the future. She wants to provide stability for her children. This is her first loan with MFP, and she pledges to be very responsible with the repayments. With the money from the loan, she plans to buy a large quantity of potatoes (Peruvian tubers) in order to increase the number of dishes she makes, and she also wants to supply her store with "panetones" (traditional Christmas cakes) in order to sell them for the holidays and make a good profit.

Translated from Spanish by Sarah Merchlewitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase more products to supply her store

loans.name: Delia

texts.es:
La Sra. Delia es propietaria de una Despensa en la ciudad de San Patricio Misiones, ubicado sobre ruta 1, es madre de 2 jóvenes, quienes viven con ella en casa propia, su marido trabaja en la ciudad de Encarnación, quien viaja constantemente.
Ella con  su esfuerzo y la de su marido lograron abrir la despensa de la cual la pareja hoy en día se sienten orgullosos ya que ayuda en gran parte para los gastos de la casa. 
Ña Delia también la cuida a su madre quien vive con ella.
La Clienta opera con mucha satisfacción con la Fundación Paraguaya  por la atención que recibe y por que mediante la misma lograron ampliar el negocio.
texts.en:
Delia is the owner of a small grocery store in the city of San Patricio Misiones, located on route 1. She is the mother of 2 youths who live with her in her own house. Her husband works in the city of Encarnacion, and he travels constantly. With the efforts of herself and her husband, Delia managed to open the store and today the couple feels very proud of this accomplishment since it helps them tremendously in paying the household expenses. Delia also cares for her mother, who lives with her. She is very satisfied with the business that she does with the Paraguayan Foundation, for the attention she receives and because through the Foundation she has managed to enlarge her business.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy basic merchandise such as cooking oil, rice, sugar, noodles, flour, drinks, bread, etc.

loans.name: Sortilegio Group

texts.es:
El grupo sortilegio está integrado por Darling S., Karla G. y Esperanza D. tres féminas trabajadoras provenientes del barrio Camilo Ortega de Managua.

En el 2002 Darling S. empezó a vender repostería en su casa y después ideo salir a ofrecerlas de manera ambulante. Karla G. desde hace tres años tiene una pulpería y Esperanza D. vende tropigas, gas licuado de dicha marca.
texts.en:
The Sortilegio group is made up of Darling S., Karla G. and Esperanza D., three working women who come from the Camilo Ortega de Managua neighborhood. In 2002, Darling S. started selling pastries from her home and then had the idea of going out and selling them as a street vendor. Karla G. has had a grocery store for the last three years and Esperanza D. sells Tropigas, liquid propane.

Translated from Spanish by Kristina Howe, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy ingredients to make pastries

loans.name: Filiberta Francisca

texts.es:
Filiberta C. de 62 años de edad, tiene una casa de cemento con solo un servicio básico que es el agua, su casa esta ubicada en el Fortín de Guayaquil, su esposo le ayuda con los gastos de la casa dirigiendo una Cooperativa de Sergio Total, tiene un hijo de 26 años.

Filiberta comenzó su negocio hace 10 años atrás con unos pequeños ahorros pudo invertir para ayudarle a su esposo con los gastos familiares, experimentando con una pequeña tienda,  ahora ella trabaja desde las 07h00 hasta las 22h00 vendiendo arroz, azúcar, atún, etc. Uno de los inconvenientes en su tienda es la competencia de su sector y el polvo que ocasional los carros ya que no esta pavimentada su calle. 

Con el préstamo quiere comprar azúcar, aceites, atún, jabón, arroz y muchos mas vivieres para su tienda. En el futuro quiere poner en conjunto con su tienda un bazar  y así incrementarlo.
texts.en:
Filiberta C. is 62 years old and has a cement house with only one basic service, which is water. Her house is located in the Fortín district of Guayaquil. Her husband helps her with the household expenses; he manages the Sergio Total Cooperative. They have a son who is 26 years old. Filiberta began her business 10 years ago, experimenting with a small store using a small amount of savings that she was able to invest to help her husband with the family expenses. Now she works from 7am until 10pm selling rice, sugar, tuna, etc. One of the drawbacks of her store is the competition in the sector and the dust that comes from the cars, since the street where she is located is not paved. With the loan she wants to buy sugar, cooking oil, tuna, soap, rice, and many other items for her store. In the future she would like to be able to add a variety store to her shop and in this way increase her business.

Translated from Spanish by Lisa Grobar, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy sugar, cooking oil, soap, rice, tuna, and other consumer goods

loans.name: Taibat

texts.en:
Taibat is 39 years old and is married with three children: 11, 9 and 5 years old. She lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. Her husband is a driver and they both contribute to supporting the family.

Taibat sells provisions, medicine, clothes and bags. One of her greatest joys is the one-on-one interaction she is able to have with her customers. She believes that having an assortment of women's clothes that is both practical and good quality will increase her sales. She is requesting the loan of N100,000 to purchase more provisions, medicines, clothes and bags to sell. She say thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes, medicines, bags and provisions to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buy carpentry supplies (lumber, nails, glue, sandpaper, accessories)

loans.name: Elsa

texts.es:
La socia Elsa es natural de la ciudad de Urcos de la provincia de Quispicanchis del departamento del Cusco y pertenece al Banco Comunal “Qori Orcco” de la Asociación Arariwa. Nuestra socia Elsa tiene 28 años, es conviviente y tiene dos hijos. Sebastián tiene siete años y Edward tiene un año de edad.
 
La socia se levanta muy temprano para hacer sus actividades del hogar como a tender a su esposo e hijos.  La socia después de hacer sus actividades del hogar tiene que ir a vender pan en la Plaza de Armas de la ciudad de Urcos. Ella nos cuenta que desde muy niña ayudaba a su mamá a elaborar el pan y los vendían todos los días pero ahora ella es independiente. Ella alquila un horno con varias compañeras de negocio y ahí preparan sus propios panes. Ella y sus compañeras desde hace 2 años atrás se les ocurrió crear un panteón especial que lo llamaron “chuta navideña” que tiene las mismas características del pan chuta (Pan redondo blando con un olor peculiar y es un pan gigante) pero le agregaron pasas y frutas. La socia y sus compañeras de negocio solo preparan este pan “Chuta navideña” para las fiestas de navidad. Nuestra socia es una mujer trabajadora y emprendedora que a pesar de las adversidades de la vida va a sacar profesionales a sus hijos. La socia requiere el préstamo para comprar mas insumos como harina, azúcar, manteca, frutas y pasas para preparar las “chutas navideñas” para navidad y año nuevo ya que por estas épocas es donde se vende más. 

La socia se encuentra agradecida por la oportunidad brindada mediante este medio y así mismo se compromete a cumplir con el pago correspondiente al cronograma.
texts.en:
Elsa is from the city of Urcos in Quispicanchis province in the Department of Cusco and is a member of the “Quori Orcco” community bank, part of the Arariwa Association. Our colleague Elsa is 28 years old, has a husband and two children. Sebastián is seven and Edward is one year old.

Elsa gets up very early in the morning to do her housework and care for her husband and children. After doing housework she has to go sell bread in the Plaza de Armas (main square) in Urcos. She tells us that since she was a small girl she helped her mother make bread and sell it every day, but now she works on her own. She rents an oven along with several business friends where they each prepare their own bread.

Two years ago she and her friends decided to create a special bread that they call “Chuta Navideña”, which is similar to Chuta bread (a large soft round loaf with a unique aroma that is traditional in Urcos), though they add raisins and fruit. Elsa and her companions only bake this bread during the Christmas holidays.

Elsa is a hardworking woman who, despite life’s challenges, wants her children to become professionals. She needs a the loan to purchase more ingredients like flour, sugar, shortening, fruit and raisins for making “Chuta Navideñas” for Christmas and New Years, especially since this is the season of her greatest sales.

Elsa is grateful for the opportunity provided by this loan, and likewise promises to pay it back according to the payment schedule.

Translated from Spanish by David Kaisel, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: The loan is needed to purchase ingredients such as flour, sugar, shortening, dried fruit and raisins

loans.name: Rosalyn

texts.en: Rosalyn is 34 years old and has been married to her husband, Noel, since 2003. She has two kids with him. Her oldest child is now fifteen years old and goes to school. She is involved in rice farming and has been doing that since she got married. She and her husband work hard at the farm to earn an income as well as for their childrens future. She has also sought the help of MFIs in the Philippines and was able to become a member of CEVI. She feels blessed for having gained access to its financial services. She is now applying for a loan of Php15, 000. She will use this loan to finance her farm.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Merry

texts.en: Merry is a 48-year-old married woman. She has children and her oldest child is now 23 years old. She wants to help improve her family’s living conditions, and she works hard to achieve that. She has invested in rice farming and has also tried raising pigs. She shares that she needs additional capital to keep her business going. She joined CEVI, and has requested to loan Php15, 000. She will use this loan to finance her farm and purchase feed for her pigs.

loans.use: Farm Supplies & Animal Feed

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of merchandise (milk, baked goods, soft drinks, vegetables, meats, fruit)

loans.name: Mira

texts.en: Mira, 44 years old, is a married woman from Agusan Del Sur. She has three children and her oldest child is 17 years old. Mira does farming for a living. Being unable to provide financially for her farm, she went to individuals, who lent money with high interest. Her income was barely enough and she was unable to save for her childrens education. When she learned about CEVI, she settled her responsibilities and joined the MFI. She said that with its low interest rate, she is able to gain an income. She is now requesting for a loan of Php15, 000. She will use this loan to finance her farm.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Femi

texts.en:
Femi is 30 years old and is married with a child. He lives in Ibadan, Oyo State, Nigeria. His wife sells clothes and they both contribute to supporting the family.

Femi sells clothes, shoes and bags. He wishes to expand and meet the needs of his customers during this festive period as the demand for clothing is very high. He is requesting the loan of N60,000 to purchase more clothes, shoes and bags to sell. He say thank you to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase more clothes, shoes and bags to sell

loans.name: Benita

texts.en: Benita does farming for a living. She is 43 years old, is married and has a 17-year-old child. She cultivates her land for rice crops. She chose to plant rice because it is a basic need among Filipinos, so it is easier to sell compared to other crops. She is now preparing her farm for planting. She will need seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs to achieve an abundant harvest, in order to provide a better income. She has requested Php15, 000 from CEVI. She will use this loan to finance her farm.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Merly

texts.en:
57-year-old Merly is a married woman. She has twelve children with her husband. Her oldest child, who is now 34 years old, does not live with them anymore. She does rice farming for a living. Having a big family, she and her husband double their efforts to have an abundant harvest each time, so that they can provide for their family’s needs. She also makes sure to spend quality time with her children.

Merly applied to CEVI to have access to financial opportunities. She has requested for a loan of Php15, 000, which will be used to finance her farm. She will be able to purchase quality seeds, fertilizers and other farming inputs needed at her farm.

loans.use: Farm Supplies

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Purchase of merchandise and livestock (electric appliances, hardware, cleaning supplies)

loans.name: Mary Ann

texts.en:
Mary Ann is a 26-year-old married woman who lives in a town in Agusan Del Sur. She has two children, the older of which is seven. She makes a living as a rice farmer, and works hand-in-hand with her husband. She also raises chickens to earn a little extra money, always making sure to manage her time well so that she can spend time with her family. She is committed to improving her family’s living conditions.

Mary Ann is a member of CEVI and is an active participant at our meetings. She has applied for a loan for PHP 12,000 to invest in her farm by buying seeds, fertilizers and other items she needs to grow a large and healthy crop.

loans.use: to buy supplies for a rice farm

loans.name: Otilia

texts.es:
La Sra. Eladia es propietaria de una Despensa en el barrio San Isidro de la Ciudad, es madre de 3 Jóvenes una mayor y dos menores de edad, vive en casa propia y todos estudiantes.
La Cliente es una mujer luchadora que ha sobresalido con sus hijos adelante, su despensa es muy bien surtida, cuenta con artículos de primera necesidad, embutidos, carnicería, artículos de limpieza, etc.
Mediante el crédito otorgado por la Fundación pudo ampliar su negocio y contar con nuevos productos de calidad y buen precio, de esto precisaba ya que en esta época las ventas aumenta masivamente.
Eladia manifiesta estar conforme trabajando con la Institución, y aprovecha la oportunidad a la confianza que se le brinda.-
texts.en:
Eladia is the proprietor of a shop in the San Isidro neighborhood in San Ignacio. She lives in her own home and is mother of three children who all study, one of whom is an adult.

She is a hardworking woman who has overcome challenges, putting her children first. Her shop is well-stocked with grocery items, meats, packaged goods, cleaning supplies, etc.

With the loan provided by the Foundation she will be able to increase her business by stocking new quality products at reasonable prices, which she needs to do since this is the season when her sales increase significantly.

Eladia asserts that she agrees to work with the Institution, and will make good use of the opportunity provided by their confidence in her.

Translated from Spanish by David Kaisel, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of merchandise for sale, such as rice, flour, sugar, noodles, baked goods, drinks, etc.

loans.name: Oreoluwa

texts.en:
Oreoluwa sells sarongs and has been in business for 15 years.  She is a member of LAPO and is a faithful client.  Oreoluwa goes to market once every two weeks to buy new stock in large quantity at a discount. 

Oreoluwa is requesting a loan of N100,000 to purchase goods in bulk.  This will enable her to meet demand during the festive season.  Oreoluwa is 35 years old and has a three children, ages are 14,10  and seven.   She says thank you to lenders as her previous loan enabled her to sell more goods to customers. She promises to pay back this new loan promptly.

loans.use: Purchase more sarongs to sell.

loans.name: Kuña Aty Kyre'y Group

texts.es:
Las integrantes que conforman el  comité Kuña aty kyre´y , actualmente se encuentran en el 8vo ciclo dentro del programa comité de mujeres son señoras que dentro de la comunidad de San Ignacio del barrio Santo Angel, donde viven, trabajan en equipo y realizan actividades en su comunidad, son muy unidas y expresan constantemente que dentro del grupo aprenden diariamente a convivir y que organizandose obtienen muchos beneficios para ellas y su comunidad a fin de progresar cada día.
En su comunidad se han destacado y todos los vecinos les acompañan en la actividades que realizan ya sean sorteos, torneos y actividades para los niños de la comunidad y desean seguir trabajando unidas para seguir creciendo en grupo y asi fortalecerse en el comité.
1
Corinda Luz A. de Paniagua
Vta. De Merceria

2
Francisca Ramona A.
Macatera

Niñera – Vta de Bijouteri
